Fantastic game with great gameplay and story, especially in the dlcs.

After 5 years of listening to nothing but praises for this game, i finally give this game a try and i was completely confuse. Everything surround the story is a complete mix bag. CDPR seems to have lock themselves in a dungoen with no access to the outside world because this game has a lot of outdated feature even for a 2015 game. And my experience was filled with annoying and sometimes game breaking bugs. The story, the characters and the world is worth the praise but the gameplay just made me wish i could play older games that did what this game did but better.

For a game that has a huge following i was excited to finally dive in and see what I'd been missing, hoping for something to fill the void between the next elder scrolls or proper fallout but alas nothing here for me.
With that said the game is beautiful and Im sure if I persisted with it I'd end up looking past the badly formed combat system, boring crafting and character progression. Its the first open world RPG where I didnt care/was not thinking about picking up everything and selling or using it in some way. I leave a positive review because i reckon if i wasnt pining after an elder scrolls i wouldnt be comparing it to that in everyway. For me i felt like i was playing a badly hashed console port with everything being dumbed down and simplified.

Got this few years after release, some minor bugs here and there but the environment remains immersive. 

Plenty of quests with great dialogue (some not so great) and some with consequences. 

Combat is plenty challenging at higher difficulties and can be quite intense. 

I noticed it's put up for sale quite often, even so, i'd recommend getting it as the visuals remain amazing.

By most accounts there is a great game here. I just couldn't find it behind the horrible fighting mechanics. Most of my time was spent playing with the 4K texture mod and using it as a benchmark for my new GPU.
Combat is very clumsy and not fun. Game is nice in a lot of ways, but still can't shake off the eurojank.
One of my favorite games! If you like Elder Scrolls, you'll like this.

PIrated the game 2 years ago to see what the fuss is about. Finished it. Went back, bought and played Witcher 1 and 2. Then bought this and now am playing the whole thing all over again. There are very few games that come close to Halo in defining the genre they belong to. The Witcher games are among them. I would strongly recommend that you play Witcher 1 and 2 before playing Witcher 3. While the gameplay mechanics in the earlier games are a bit clumsy, the story more than makes up for it.
10/10 on all aspects except maybe the combat grind.

The Witcher 3, el juego perfecto del que todo el mundo habla como referente de los RPGs, no es tan perfecto ni tan referente. AÃºn asÃ­ es un buen juego, pero para nada es para endiosarlo como hace la mayorÃ­a de gente.

Su nivel tÃ©cnico es muy alto, con grÃ¡ficos y ubicaciones muy trabajados estÃ©ticamente, con una optimizaciÃ³n muy buena y llena de detalles.

Como historia no hay nada que reprocharle, tanto la principal como las secundarias son oro, con personajes carismÃ¡ticos y cambios de guion buenos. Algunas con una profundidad remarcable que te posicionaran sobre un bando u otro segÃºn tus principios morales. Se nota que hay literatura detrÃ¡s de cada palabra. Lo que me parece horrible es que un juego donde la historia es tan protagonista no estÃ© doblado al castellano, y aunque tenga subtÃ­tulos en nuestro idioma, te pierdes un montÃ³n de acciones de las cinemÃ¡ticas por leerlos, para eso que pongan un fondo oscuro y los textos encima y serÃ­a lo mismo porque la mayorÃ­a de veces no he llegado a ver ni una expresiÃ³n facialâ€¦

Hablando de su mundo abierto: sÃ­, es enorme, pero tambiÃ©n me ha dado una sensaciÃ³n de vacÃ­o y poco inmersivo, me explicarÃ©. Si bien cada vez que llegas a un pueblo o ciudad parece que vas a notar una sensaciÃ³n nueva, parece un corta y pega de POIs y NPCs, donde el tablÃ³n de anuncios es el centro y la herrerÃ­a y cantina completan todo lo interesante para la aventura. Incluso en las grandes ciudades se tiene esa sensaciÃ³n de estar solo porque los NPCs y las viviendas son atrezo en cantidades descomunales. 

En el tema de aventura tampoco me he sentido muy inmerso (a excepciÃ³n de las misiones de contrato) porque puedes irte a explorar el mapa y encontrar ubicaciones muy planas, sin ningÃºn atisbo de picarte el gusanillo aventurero al encontrar una cueva o naufragio, es lo que son: cuevas lineales nada laberÃ­nticas ni profundas sin tesoros o trampas especiales y naufragios yermos en interacciÃ³n. Una lÃ¡stima porque teniendo ubicaciones tan majestuosas podrÃ­an haber hecho grandes cosas. AdemÃ¡s, la mÃºsica que te acompaÃ±a durante el viaje es siempre la misma, muy pocos temas para un juego tan grande, te cansas de ir encima de Sardinilla cabalgando durante kilÃ³metros escuchando una y otra vez el mismo tema. En mi opiniÃ³n los temas no son tan Ã©picos como los de otros juegos del mismo gÃ©nero.

En lo referente al combate he de decir que es muy simple y ortopÃ©dico. Tanto los movimientos de Geralt como los patrones de ataque e IA de los enemigos son muy bÃ¡sicos y repetitivos, y los niveles de dificultad solo cambian el daÃ±o recibido, nada de IA mejorada segÃºn la dificultad.
Sobre el Ã¡rbol de mejoras del personaje es sencillo, pero cumple su cometido en funciÃ³n de como quieras que sea tu estilo de juego. Las habilidades y la gestiÃ³n de brebajes y pociones mejoran el combate en cierta manera.

Uno de los puntos fuertes y con el que mÃ¡s me he divertido es el â€œminijuegoâ€ de cartas Gwent. Durante la aventura te vas a ir encontrando con oponentes que te irÃ¡n retando con barajas cada vez mÃ¡s duras y con recompensas de cartas especiales que mejorarÃ¡n tus manos. Lo malo es que sacaron el juego oficial aparte y perdiÃ³ la esencia de Ã©ste.

Una cosa que me ha parecido muy pobre ha sido el tema del loot y robo de objetos de casas, cajas, etc. Resulta que, si quieres saquear cualquier cosa, de lo Ãºnico que te tienes que preocupar es de que no haya ningÃºn guardia cerca, si no ni siquiera sus legÃ­timos dueÃ±os te increparÃ¡n o darÃ¡n aviso como que eres un ladrÃ³n. 

Me dejo unas cuantas cosas, pero para concluir dirÃ© que no sÃ© como gente que ha jugado a muchos juegos puede elevarlo a obra maestra cuando es plano en la mayorÃ­a de mecÃ¡nicas. Aunque tenga muchÃ­simo contenido eso no le hace tampoco bueno, porque es lo mismo una y otra vez, para quÃ© quiero una casa llena de armarios si todo lo que hay es la misma basura repetida, para eso que pongan un solo armario. This game is amazing. Just amazing. The story is wonderful and so fun to play, it never really gets repetitive and boring. The game play might seem overwhelming and complicated at first but eventually (and you wont have to wait that long) it makes sense and you can start to pick some play styles. The game play overall is so fun and satisfying. Using spells is very fun. The graphics, despite this game having been released a while back are still pretty good and with some mods can look absolutely amazing.

This game is absolutely amazing and if it is on sale, i would 100% recommend getting it.

Been waiting to play this game for a while, finally got a new laptop to play it on and enjoying it...

I bought the Game of the Year edition and it was one of the best bought game, hell, it is THE Best game that i have ever bought. I heard of the witcher game population, and it is so much more after i played it.

The story was splendidly written, the main quest, side quest and all, never a point where you got lost or bored of the main quest and decide to do other things u could in game, though there are many side quest and discovery in this game but ALL of them are decent. The DLC quest by far is the one that i felt its not a cash grabber: the depth and the plot , characters design and all are decent designed that you wish for even more....

Gameplay is kind of a action RPG, with decent combat system and level up to unlock new skill etc... 

As for soundtrack, " otherworldy amazing " isn't enough to even describe the slightest of it

With the release of Cyberpunk 2077 i notice there were complains regarding to Witcher 3's plot being too long, and yet for some fans, including myself i would say otherwise.

Gameplay      9.5/10
Soundtrack   9.7/10
Graphic           9/10
Story          100/10

Conclusion: It's a must for a gamer, It's an adventure one shalt never miss

Take a good look at what capitol and markets will do to even a company with the best intentions. And FFS, stop pre-ordering games.

I don't know what to say other than that this game is almost perfect. 
My only issue is that ending up over level is very easy for someone who does all the quests and that this turns combat, even on the highest difficulty, into something too easy in many cases. That isn't to say that there are no challenges but in general I would actually say avoid doing too many side quests in each playthrough.

This game is brilliant. An open world experience that keeps you intrigued, entertained and enthralled. The story is good, and the world feels alive. Still holds up well even in 2021. 10 outta 10 will play again.

One of the greatest action RPG's I've ever played

If there's one complaint I'd [i] have [/i] to choose, it'd be that the expansiveness of the quests and it's overwhelming map size outpaces the variety of The Witcher 3's combat system, which proves to be a bit too simple after spending hundreds of hours hacking and slashing

But despite weaknesses in Geralt's agility and fighting styles, the game has consistently provided me with comfort and immersion with it's dense narrative, fantastic script writing, and an endlessly enchanting adaptation of it's wildly interesting base material

While having nearly 800 hours in a single player game may imply that I have done multiple playthroughs, that is not the case here, I have one save file on PS4 (276 hours) and one save file on PC (500+ hours, haven't finished Blood and Wine on PC)... that's really all that you should need to tell you about how much I really like this game. That being said, it's time demanding approach to the open world genre will either hit or miss depending on how much you are willing to dedicate to one game, so definitely keep that in mind before purchasing

10/10

The game is just perfect!
You want a good story? Just look at the view? Kill some monster on some quests? Just walk randomly listening the songs and appreciating what happens during your journey?
You can play that as many time you want, a giant map with a lot of treasures, caves, monsters and humans to fight. The story is amazing too! You can just rush to play the main story or appreciate everything the gave have to offer.

About settings, I'm using the Ryzen 5 3600 / RTX 2060 / 16gb DDR4 3600mhz / 1080p and the game is just perfect, everything on Ultra and playing around 80~90fps, sometimes reaching 100fps.

I played this game for more than 200 hours on Xbox before purchasing it on Steam to have better graphics and so on.

This is my favorite game of all time, I think. CD Projekt Red once again makes a masterpiece, with intensely good character and quest writing, a beautiful open world, and solid story, and fun casual combat and build potential.

The crowning jewel of this game is the quest writing, for sure, as one often feels like what they're doing is important enough and well crafted enough to be a main story mission, only to find out that it was a monster contract. I've never so avidly poured so much time into one game when I finally played it as this amazing work of art.

In addition to a fantastic base game, both DLCs are amazing, with Blood and Wine often referred to as the greatest expansion to any video game (maybe next to Brave New World for Civilization V). Toussaint and its offerings could easily stand alone as its own game.

This game goes on sale often, and I don't think the average gamer would regret picking it up.

Does anything need to be said?

I want to start by saying that I have played a lot of games so far, I am more of a shooter-player. But I also like RPGs, a few years ago I first tried to play Witcher 3, I didn't understand anything and it seemed very boring, I deleted it and reinstalled it to give it a try, but nothing. Until at one point I played somewhere at 20 hours and I didn't leave the game at all, I stayed for 5-6 hours each day and I didn't realize how fast time passes. I was one with the game, I felt every emotion and state that the game sent, I don't even know what to say about the soundtrack. It's just brilliant, the story of Wildhunt gave me goosebumps, and not to mention DLC. Simply exceptional (Blood and Wine) being the best.
10/10 - a great game that will remain with me a long time.

A very focused game. It captures the feeling of the characters and the world very well, and gives the player plenty of freedom to experience them how they wish. Doesn't try and be everything at once either, no character customization, few weapons to choose from, and limited abilities to keep you from becoming OP. What is there, however, is very polished and re-playable, and teaches you to become a Witcher in a world teeming with terrifying, dangerous, and stunning monsters. 

One of the only games I've played that gives you stories and characters that stick with you long after you're done. Couldn't recommend more.

The Gamer game:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is the best game the company that shall not be named ever made [finished it shortly after Cyberpunk 2077 released]. A beautiful piece of art and a staple in video game history. I love how you approach it at your own pace â€“ though it should have some parts of the game (e.g. Gwent) explained more thoroughly (I have googled stuff fairly often). The world, the characters and the story are phenomenal, while the gameplay looks comparatively worse.
My suggestion to new players is to try different difficulties and remove the line that leads you to your objective.
And if youâ€™re a fan of this game I can also recommend the Witcher 2 as well as the book series!

Best game ever made i could say, even tho it has some bugs but they do not affect the gameplay, actualy are kind of funny.

A game where you will feel unimaginable emptiness for weeks to come after you finish it. From monster-infested swamps of Velen to shores of Skellige where harsh but beautiful tides wash. A fair violet-eyed beloved that will make your knees tremble under her loving yet piercing gaze, an ashen haired lass that you will come to call your daughter, your destiny and an old wolf who will make you cry rivers towards the end. I will miss all of them. Words can only say so much therefore after a certain point one can do nothing but admire this well-crafted masterpiece. 



So long, Witcher.

The game was way too overhyped for what it actualy offered. 
I was told that i whould get an awesome RPG expirience, where all my choices had consequences.
What i was given was a mediocre melee focused game, where non of my choices in the early parts mattered. Neither the fact that i prefer to work for less or no money at all was represented in any way in the story.
The fact that i chose hand to hand comabt over sword combat when fighting humans was completly ingnored and i was just forced a sword in my hand in cutscenes.
 ItÂ´s a game that has to shove unnescessary overly sexual conent into every other cutscene of the main campaign. It also lacks proper ways of teaching you what you have to do for certain enemies. Yes i know the bestiary tells me what things are "useful" against an enemy. But i whould say that telling me that i need a certain ability or item to even be able to damage an enemy counts as something different.
The fact that the game decides when youa re in combat and when not is also just such an ass backwards idea that i canÂ´t explain how anyone at CDPR could think itÂ´s a good idea. Especialy since there are enemies that can damage you while beeing outside the range of this "feature". In other words, even though i had the ability to deflect arrows, i wasnÂ´t allowed to use it because the game decided i wasnÂ´t in combat.

Pro:  huge open world.  Massive content for the money.

Con:  Too much time on cutscenes.

in a nutshell - if you're planning to get a game that is

A) Open-World
B) A RPG

Efsane bir oyun.Hikayesi,karakteri (Ã¶zellikle Yen<3) Ã§ok iyi.Aksiyon muazzam 10/10

Honestly the best game I've ever played. 11/10. 
If you haven't played it yet, I full heartedly recommend. You won't be disappointed. 
Your actions will affect how the story will progress and end. Every side quest is unique. Every contract is unique. Even the smallest things you've done can change everything. Combat is fun and engaging. The music, oh the music. In my opinion it is the best music ever created for a game. I'm truly in love with the music. Voice acting is extremely good. Has a lot funny and emotional moments. The main game is insanely good, but the DLCs makes this game even better. New Game + here I come.

Absolut beast of a game in terms of story, visuals, combat system with nearly endless possibilities of entertainment.
100% recommended to anybody who loves fantasy and certainly Witcher world from books or TV series (Geralt looks much better ingame than Henry Cavil despite the fact he's really good actor and witcher geek himself).

Also don't forget to check DLCs which are designed as whole separated storylines with plenty of new stuff to discover.
Old school DLC where you got stuff instead of expensive mini updates as EA games loves to release.

Toss a coin to your witcher and to CD Projekt Red for this one.
Worth every coin.

Such a banger game. I can't express to anybody enough how good this game was. The crafting and brewing system may seem intimidating at first for a complete noob, but to be honest, I only had to use crafting and brewing for like one mission.  I was the person who tried the game out for a couple hours, then thought it wasn't going anywhere so I refunded it. That was a huge mistake. One day I thought about it and was like "You know what, I really want to get into this game", so I got it again, powered through it and am so glad that I did. It is kind of rough getting started, like grinding to the recommended level for the first contract you do, but after that, your levels just start taking off. So that's some advice. All in all, 10/10 game, I also couldn't be more happy with the ending.

the story of this game good but the combat system is really ass 
this game is fun but if you like rpg only fight stuff this game is maybe not for you
One of thee best games ever made! Period!

This game is a masterpiece, rife with quite possibly the best story I've encountered in gaming. Humor. Romance. Nostalgia. What does this game not have? Heck, Witcher 3 even has a fully-fleshed out card game within the game that in itself is exceptional. Whether you play for completion or the story, this game will excite you. At the hardest difficulty, the game can feel extremely daunting, especially at the beginning as you begin to understand enemy patterns and the intricate combat mechanics. Not to mention, this game is visually breathtaking.

There's not many games that live up to expectations, especially those as lofty as the Witcher 3 has received, but even 5-6 years later, this game met and truthfully surpassed those expectations. 

Even the smallest of side characters feel well developed and significant. And Geralt. Oh my. Despite his often monotonous and gravelly tone, there is just so much character and wit in every action. There's also no better way to say this than that the story makes sense. Nothing feels like filler. And the actions you take feel like they matter and are appropriate actions to take given the circumstances. The DLC is also fantastic.

CDPR and every other gaming company should strive to achieve what the Witcher 3 has.

Great plot, amazing graphics (at least for the year it was released), the gameplay is nothing groundbreaking but itÂ´s so good and fun, the music is beautiful and the game gives you tons of things to do and discover without feeling repetitive, not to say the DLCs are really good and long, totally worth the money, AMAZING game.

The only thing I don't like about this game is the horse control/combat, but everything else is just *chef's kiss*. Gorgeous visuals, amazing combat system, rich characters and story. I really hope this isn't the end of the Witcher series, but if it is, then I couldn't think of a better way game to end it on.

[h1][i] The best action RPG ever !!![/i][/h1]
[list]
[*] Review with Platinum (100% Achievement)
[/list]

This is an action role-playing game that won 'A Game of the Year edition 2016'. It was designed in a massive open-world with the backdrop of magic, monsters, mysteries, and the medieval atmosphere (13th Century) based on the fictional story of The Witcher series written by Andrzej Sapkowski, a famous Polish fantasy writer. It is a sequel third-person perspective to The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings and The Witcher. Players will take on the role of Geralt of Rivier or Butcher of Blaviken who was a legendary witcher of the School of the Wolf. His main mission in this episode is the search for his adopted daughter, Cirilla Fiona Elen Riannon (Ciri) along with tons of deeply designed gameplay, mini-game, and quest systems. Moreover, there are two outstanding expansions that were also released including Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine. 

[b] Pros: [/b]
- Careful gameplay features and useful elements for players
- Expressive main characters and memorable supporting NPCs
- Flexibility and freedom to navigate the massive beautiful world
- Realistic and tactical combat styles for both melee or ranged weapons and a rudimentary form of magic (Sign)
- Recognizable sub-components such as chat dialogue (voice and narration), items, prostitutes, and costumes
- Absorbing story that reflects the personal conflict and the regional politics 
- Different quests and decisions that lead to distinctive storylines
- Nice mini-game design, especially Gwent the Witcher card game
- Availability of mods and other third-party applications that discriminates the gameplay style

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Long and redundant loading screen
One of the most amazing RPGs of all time.

Very fun open world RPG game-- the side quests are especially good
Ã“timo game vale totalmente o investimento

Play this game. The only true RPGs I had played before were from Bethesda. This game is completely different. The story is compelling and captivating, the combat is engaging and fun, and quests are mysterious and consequential. As if that was not enough, the game runs as well as I could ever ask. Does it have bugs? Yes, a few annoying ones for people with rebound controls. Do I really care? Not really, because the game is just that good.

Es una obra maestras, de los mejores RPG que he jugado en la vida, hice todas la misiones, hasta la de recoger un sarten para una viejita. La historia es excelente, no puedes anticipar lo que va a pasar. Los actores que hicieron las voces son muy buenos, el script es genial. Los graficos son tan buenos, que hay momentos en los que me quedaba solo aprenciando lo maravilloso del mundo. TENES que jugar este juego, a todos les va a gustar
totally worth it, sale or not!

The game becomes uninteresting after a while because while well written you are essentially doing the same thing over and over again. The game play is simplistic in that you dodge, attack, and repeat. After repeating the same attacks for dozens of hours you get so good at it that the game becomes extremely easy. Levelling up takes a long time and the rewards are limited, and the magic is simple and not interesting to play with. The great graphics kept me captivated for a long time and the scenes are great to look at, but eventually the beauty of the game only captivates you for so long until you discover that every mission is the same; You go out and kill some enemies. I played for over 100 hours and slowly got tired of it until I decided to quit and play something else, and I don't really feel like going back to it now.

Getting lost for hours upon hours playing a darned good immersive RPG experience; fun and yet challenging combat with men, beasts, both magical and non-magical, soaking in an epic fantasy setting with rich ambience and exploring a fascinatingly vivid world...this gives you the full course meal of medieval/supernatural RPGs. It still stands out as probably the very best experience a lover of RPGs can get for their money, an excess of 5 years after its release! An absolute GEM, I'm totally madferrit!!

Es lohnt sich das Spiel auch auf hÃ¶herem Schwierigkeitsgrad zu spielen, weil die KÃ¤mpfe so recht taktisch werden. Viele Quests, viele Sammelaufgaben (die grÃ¶ÃŸtenteils auch SpaÃŸ machen) und noch mehr Inhalt dank DLCs. Es lohnt sich!

The Witcher 3 is an amazing game to experience, however it is probably the most boring game gameplay-wise I have ever laid my hands upon. Get this game for the amazing story and characters you'll get to experience. Even on the highest Difficulty setting this game is a breeze as long as you aren't allocating skill points like an idiot. 

Combat gets reduced to mindless dodging, attack, parry gameplay pretty much from the get go. Potions and Oils only literally reducing how many times you have to press the attack button to end an encounter. Even Alchemy and Sign builds quickly break the game even on Death March difficulty. 

However this didn't really detract from how mesmerized and entertained I was with the story I got to experience. I'm yet to start Blood and Wine. Hearts of Stone already delivered an even more interesting story than the base game did so I'm looking forward to getting into Blood and Wine.
Great game-play, complex stories, fleshed out characters. Plus Gwent gets addicting!

GerÃ§ekten harika bir oyun.Ama bu oyunu oynamadan Ã¶nce diÄŸer 2 oyunun hikayesini biraz Ã¶ÄŸrenin witcher evrenine daha kolay alÄ±ÅŸÄ±rsÄ±nÄ±z.Zaten Ã§oÄŸu dlc bedava,onlarÄ± almanÄ±zÄ± Ã¶neririm.Oyun hakkÄ±nda ise herkes ile her an etkileÅŸime girebiliyorsunuz.Manzaralar,arazilere,doÄŸaya geldiÄŸimiz zaman gÃ¶rdÃ¼klerim arasÄ±nda en iyilerinden.SavaÅŸ ve bÃ¼yÃ¼ler Ã§ok gerÃ§ekÃ§i.Atlar,kurtlar,kÃ¶pekler hatta tavÅŸanlar bile Ã§ok gerÃ§ekÃ§i,canavarlarda Ã§ok baÅŸarÄ±lÄ±.KÄ±sacasÄ± oyunu almanÄ±zÄ± tavsiye ederim,bedava dlc leri de.GerÃ§ekten ÅŸuana kadar gÃ¶rdÃ¼ÄŸÃ¼m en iyi oyunlardan.

This is the best game to have come out yet.

They added a jump button! that really annoyed me not being able to jump in the other Witcher games. What is there to say that others haven't? The game excels in the storytelling, writing and voice acting. CD Project Red make it all look easy, play other games and most seem to really struggle with these things.

To be honest, i'm not in love with this series in the way a lot of other people are, the actual gameplay never did anything for me, and i'm not that into fantasy RPG's, but the storytelling is so strong that it can rise above the mediocre gameplay.

A few things i didn't like... being able to fail quests, there's a few times where depending on your actions or lack of actions you will fail a quest, they don't warn you either, that annoyed me.

Also there was one time where a dialogue choice lead me to fight a key character to the death, and i didn't realize that's what would happen or i wouldn't have picked it! 

Anyway, you get your moneys worth, this is a huge game, the expansion Blood and Wine adds a whole new kingdom and region which adds like 50 more hours of story, it's worth checking out if you haven't played it yet.

IÂ´m definitely not typical RPG player, but as I knew the Witcher books which I really liked, I gave it a try. First few hours I was still not convinced, but deeper I got into the story more I started to enjoy. When I finished the main story line after 70 hours I was kind of sad that it is over, specially as few ten hours of the story are really intense with fantastic flow. So I bought both DLSs and continue my monster slaying carrier :) thumbs up 100%, I might even try some more PRG games

One of the best western RPGs no doubt. The game actually deserves praising it gets. I finished this game about 4 times on ps4 and once on PC and I still managed to find new things. The story is decent, side quests are on a whole another level. Some people say the combat system is bad, but there's nothing bad about it really, it can be fun and challenging at times. The lore and setting are rich and interesting thanks to books, but the execution of it by CD Projekt is top notch, environments and graphics are very good and the soundtrack gives you chills sometimes.

Honestly one of the best games I've ever played. Generally, the gameplay was amazing, the story is REALLY in-depth and the combat was pretty good, despite it being a weak point. There are multiple endings and DLC's, so I doubt that I'll be done with this game for a while.

Best rpg of this generation, a must for sure.

According to Playstation I have right around 200 hours in this game on console. In my opinion, the second greatest game ever made next to RDR2, but I could see a valid argument for it deserving the #1 spot. The story, the world, the combat, everything is 10/10. This game is the true definition of an RPG.
Top 5 RPGs de todos os tempos pra mim.
MÃ¡s allÃ¡ de decir que es un juegazo, es uno (por no decir el Ãºnico) que me ha hecho llorar.
jogo perfeito apenas... historias e batalhas muitos boas e insanas, muito viciante

What can I say that hasn't been said before. Simply amazing sum up this game. If you like story rich, open world RPGs then buy the whole thing, expansions and all. In my book it ranks up there with Red Dead 2 as one of the finest games ever made. So much to do, an awesome story, great handling, and at this point in it's life it is a great value. What you get is so much more than what you pay for, and even having been out for years now the visuals still hold up. A true 5 out of 5 game.
this game is really amazing. big massive open world and a tons of quest that even each quest has their own perspective and story.

So I got to the game five years late and it is still a blast. It feels like there is endless sidequests to find, monsters to fight and treasure to discover. The story is fun and doesn't really require much knowledge of the previous games to enjoy. Slight learning curve to the combat and inventory system but other than that it is pretty fantastic. With a huge modding community  that improve everything from the rain effects to the colour of an item, you'll not regret playing this one. Definitely on the best games ever and getting it on sale seems like a crime, one I'd commit again.

BEst rpg game,  only bad thing if you ask me is that teritory has quest lvl same , so i think its better 1-10 lvl one teritory , and next 10 to 20 lvl and ccc..

While it's not my favourite game of all time by a long shot I genuinely enjoyed the time I spend with the game. I grinded out all of the achievements, completed every quest I found and had my fun with the quality of life mods the nexus offers. So you could say I liked it.

I was happily suprised that some of my choices had consequences long after I had made them. The game does not cheese it's way through desicion making. You really have to think about your answer.

By the way play the game on the original voice sync. I played it in german and some of the dialog option were the exact opposite of what I wanted to say. All of a sudden I pissed of a character that I wanted to befriend. Really sucks in a game that is 85% Dialog. But that just as a sidenote.

I played the game on deathmarch from start to finish and was a little bit disappointed by the difficulty. I was expecting way more deaths than actually occured during my playthrough.

However I really enjoyed the gear system. Although there was less focus on giving me a chance to display my stuff than I would have wanted.

The game gives you all of this cool armor and weapons and then you only get the player-home in the secound DLC and there these armor racks that can only hold specific kinds of armorpieces. urgh...

The combat is alright. And thats about it. Kind of repetitive after a couple of hours but still engaging enough to keep me hooked somehow. Probably because it reminds me of Assassins Creed a little bit.

Half of the work is done by the soundtrack which I could not get enough of during the battles. Sometimes I deliberately stopped attacking and only evaded my enemy so I could strike them matching to the Battle OST. For me this is almost the best part about this game second only to the world building.

CDPR knows how to make you invested in a Gameworld. I especially fell in love with skellige, it's OST, the clan rivalries, it's map design, the unique enemys compared to the rest of the main game and the characters.

All in all I'd say if the game is on a 50% discount it's a buy for most people that want to have an engaging story. If I could change one thing about the Witcher 3 I probably would tie up some loose ends the story left me with.

I don't want to spoil anything. Just be wary that not every quest has a satisfying ending. Just because sometimes it does not have a proper ending at all. That goes for one main quest and several side quests in my opinion.

It's a good game with some missed opportunitys. Would buy again if I was given the choice. I got it in a 50% sale so 25â‚¬ for the Game of the Year edition.

To wrap this up my score is a 7/10.

I totally recommend this game on console platforms but I think the pc version is pretty lazy.  I find myself minimizing the game and having to look up simple things like how to use this crossbow the game just handed me without bothering to explain how to  equip and use.  Also I had it forget my controller exists when the batteries died out during gameplay even though i put in new ones and I again have to look up how to get it to switch back to the controller mode from keyboard and mouse mode.  Why do I have to look this up because when i replaced the batteries and turned the controller back on it didnt change back to controller mode automatically and it doesnt notice that the controller  exists when i restart with it on...  so yea I recommend the game its a classic just better off on the console platform like it was apparently designed to be played I find its just annoying on pc.

Personally my #1 game of all time. It looks beautiful, it has a great story (read the books and play the two games before this to have the ultimate experience), combat is nice with the signs. I especially love how it feels like (and more often than not) every decision you make impacts some part of the world in a good or bad way. It is also a very harsh world, forcing you to choose between two evils. This coupled with the fact that your decisions actually impact the world makes is so that you always have to be on your toes. The world also has tiny details which gives it life. If there is one gripe I had it is that I couldn't make it harder, completing my second playthrough on the hardest difficulty (and every subsequent one) but it's not meant to be a Souls game (and if you want that level of difficulty go play those games) so I can't fault it for that.

Very good game. Awesome graphics and interactive gameplay.

Amazing game in every way I can think of, story rich, and they put so much attention into the details, you have different endings based on your decisions, but also, the outcome of some (quite some) of the side quests can vary depending on your approach, decisions, dialogues can vary depending on which side quests you've done.
Open world is pretty vast, and you have different options for your build, from armor to skills, works for different kind of gamers.
Not only that but it has beautiful graphics with gorgeous landscapes and the music is delightful!
DLC content is worth it, no doubt about it.
Just Overwhelming!

I love this game and i got the best ending haha

Witcher 3 is one of the best games, if not the best, I have ever played. There's literally nothing wrong about it other than Roach, I hate Roach with a burning passion, however, even this mentally challenged horse will be great sometimes.
 
This is a 10/10 game, no discussions. It's an amazing rich story, with awesome characters and great dialogues. It's so damn beautiful and it's pretty sights will still amaze you even for a 6 year old game. At times you'll just take a moment and admire the atmosphere and looks. 

If you are like I was, and for some obscure reason you have not yet played this masterpiece, don't give it any second thoughts, just do it. You'll get tens, or even hundreds if you really want to enjoy it to the fullest (at this given moment I have 174 hours played and am still not done with everything I can do), of hours of entertainment and enjoyment. To me this is a piece of entertainment art that will forever live as one of the best games in history. 

There's no reason not to play it and if you call yourself a gamer, you cannot not enjoy this gem.
PS: This game taught me that stealing from the poor and making them poorer will have absolutely no consequences, it's great!
This game is actually insane, can't believe the depth and choice you get, a truly immersive experience as well. Amazing, 10/10
10/10 if you want a game that will keep you occupied for a long ass time
Just buy it you know you want to.
An all time favorite, well worth it

There is literally so many good things I could say about this game if I wrote it all in this review it would be 10 pages, I'm 100% serious too. 5 years after this games release and it still looks and feels amazing, every single aspect of the gameplay is fully fleshed out in every way, legitimately a masterwork. 12/10

but fuck gwent that shits boring as fuck. I miss dice poker.

I won't say it's the greatest game of all time.

But if isn't, nothing ever will be.

Dieses Spiel ist, das muss man einfach sagen, eine Wucht. Ãœberall gibt es etwas zu entdecken, Monster zu bekÃ¤mpfen oder kleine Events zu bewÃ¤ltigen, alles mit einer groÃŸen Mission im Hintergrund, das "Kind der Prophezeiung" zu finden. Man trifft auf viele alte Bekannte und hilft ihnen. Im gesamten Spiel sind auÃŸerdem viele liebevolle NebenauftrÃ¤ge und AuftrÃ¤ge verteilt, die alle eine eigene Geschichte erzÃ¤hlen mit allem was dazu gehÃ¶rt: Konflikte zwischen Charakteren, BeweggrÃ¼nde der einzelnen Charakteren innerhalb der Nebengeschichte- und alles vÃ¶llig seperat zur Hauptstory! Man merkt wirklich wieviel Liebe zum Detail die Entwickler besitzen und bekommt ein sehr gutes Spielerlebnis. Die Steuerung ist nach einiger Zeit vÃ¶llig natÃ¼rlich, sowohl mit Controller als auch mit Tastatur und das Kampfsystem bietet viel Platz, sodass jeder seinen eigenen Kampfstil finden kann. Allerdings muss man sagen dass das Spiel ab und an ein paar Bugs hat, z.B. das Loot oder Tiere fliegen oder Texturen ab und an ein wenig spÃ¤t laden. Die Grafik ist fÃ¼r ein Spiel von 2015 auch ziemlich gut, da habe ich wenig zu bemÃ¤ngeln. Ich empfehle dieses Spiel allen die auch nur Interesse an Fantasy/RPG/Spiele mit guter Story haben, dieses Spiel hat jegliches Lob verdient! Ferner kann ich hierzu auch die DLC empfehlen, beide bieten hervorragende Storylines und Quests und Blood and Wine ein sehr schÃ¶nes neues Gebiet, welches ich fast besser als im Originalspiel fand.

- awesome storytelling, main quests keep their urgency even in the vast open world
- awesome characters that feel life-like, plastic and their ambivalent personalities put you on an emotional rollercoaster
- making tough decisions in quests results often in grave, unexpected outcomes
- awesome world and locations that bring the essence of their inspiration to life
- awesome soundtrack that often brings spine chills
- wonderful moments in stories that stay in memories forever
- side quests are rarely dumb, really worth completing
- Gwent inside-game actually fun and addictive
- DLCs are just as awesome as the original main storyline, managed to make the same (if not greater) emotional impact in half the time
- RPG skill tree is ok, skills are practical and useful
- fighting system enjoyable, engaging and just
- with HD texture pack mod, the game was still decent in 2020
it made me an emotional wreck
melhor RPG que ja joguei na minha vida!

The Witcher 3 hands down is the best game I have ever played in my life for various reasons, first and foremost, the brilliant series of Novels this game was built upon which gave the game the most powerful and dramatic story I've ever seen in a video game. The storytelling was consistent and amazing with a great deal of different characters, amazing plot twists, and a vast world with different races, realms, and creatures that fight and thrive alongside one another and coexist in the most bloody and spiteful way. Secondly, the gameplay is Awesome and rich and was precisely implemented to exploit the witcher's abilities and to test the players' approaches and playing styles. thirdly, the choices and their consequences, this was a brilliant way of approaching the game by basically saying that there's no moral high ground here, you are a person who has trade. a traveler who is traveling along the journey and got to make choices that will benefit you or others the most and have to learn and live with the consequences of your choices. I liked that way more than the ultimate good character or the justified villain aka the usual approach to video game stories. Fourthly, the DLC's can easily be a stand alone games story wise, Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine are too good to be complimentary, the story is marvelous and rich and tragic that shows us how Geralt's choices can come to haunt them. Finally, this game is a work of art and every gamer shouldn't deprive him/herself from such a wonderful and rich experience

The best game of 2015 and one of the very best RPGs ever made. "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" provides an unbelievably huge open world, filled with dangerous monsters, well written characters and the best side quests the RPG-genre has to offer. I am still playing it after finishing the story. Even if the main story line could have been better, especially the Wild Hunt didn't feel frightening and dangerous enough to be really memorable villains. But don't worry, they did it way better with the first DLC: "Hearts of Stone". After all the world of "The Witcher 3" is something every gamer should experience, you won't regret spending up to over 100 hours in it. Collapse

Wild Hunt invests much more in the slow connection with the player, than in the fast, shallow and "childish" excitement. And I think that was what the series needed. A game that will provide you with rich content, the right RPG mechanics and an interactive, lively and compelling world. The Poles, although they did not need it, rebuilt their relationship with the public, piece by piece, from the beginning. The title starts warmly, highlighting the absolute basics and in the process unfolds its beautiful virtues. If you think about it, it takes guts to radically change the whole philosophy and architecture of a series that was loved. It takes courage to give such a game, which is based on everything in the long run, to an audience that is waiting for its "jaws to go" when it puts the disc in the console. This means that there in Warsaw, some do not rest and certainly do not swim in bathtubs with rose petals. They have a passion, they have an appetite for work, they have a goal and we will do very well to give them the recognition and praise they deserve.
Sehr cooles und interessantes Spiel! Nur zu empfehlen

Witcher 3 is a beautiful open world that juxtaposes violence with beauty. It's fantastic detailing reveals the consequences of your actions. Armor designs, potion system, and sign upgrades provide an excellent sense of growth. Brilliant art direction, with a dense open world in which it pays to get lost in just to see what you stumble upon next. The quality of the writing of quests and their interconnection is amazing !

This is the most enjoyable single player game I've ever had the pleasure of playing. The story, the choices, the fighting and scenery are unmatched. Making this most likely the best single player game on the steam market. The game holds endless potential and a high replayability value since every little choice you make affects the ending of multiple story lines in the game. Just get it, you wont regret it, my only regret is not buying it earlier.
Game with player choice and consequence done right! Its been fun playing it so far!

I have owned this game for a long time. but I just had time to install and play. my conclusion after playing this game for a few hours: it's a good game, great graphics, interesting story. suitable for those who like to linger in gaming.
Played The Game for 28 hours beat the game and both dlcs pretty fun overall not as fun as i thought it would be and especially not as long.

wow... where do i even start. i first tried out this game exactly four years ago right when i got into pc gaming. at the time, i couldn't get myself past the bloody baron arc and put down the game to play overwatch instead. i decided to buy a legit copy of the game on steam and i finally had the motivation to restart and experience the highly proclaimed witcher experience, and this time i was quite absorbed. now only four years later, have i completed the base game and both dlcs. 

the thing about this game and most long single player games in general is that it requires a lot of patience and motivation. the reason i stopped playing this game every once in a while was because i didn't have the balls to press 'play' and commit the energy to be immersed in the world. at the time i would of rather play mmos with crappy stories then 'waste' my time playing single player games. i thought, ' whats the point? even if this game has an amazing story, i cant show any of my gear/ achievements off to anyone'. so i would get off the game for months, then get back on, having to relearn the entire story/ characters/ quests over again. so why did i keep playing? 

it is because witcher 3 at times offered some of the best, most emotional and immersive gaming experiences i've ever had. i can just lists some quests off the top of my head that were extremely memorable for their depth, emotions, and beauty : carnal sins, reunion with ciri, the wedding quest and scenes of a marriage from HOS, and the fairy tale world in BaW. these quests made me truly feel like i was in the world of witcher, as cliche as it sounds. 

regarding the story / world:

i thought the base game was good, but the DLC were excellent in my opinion, in particular hearts of stones, which i will talk about later. the base game contains very beautiful, fleshed out regions with memorable characters to fill the world, and a decent, but quite flawed story imo. the base game has the most content, obviously, and contains some of the most iconic scenes in the game (big battle, finding ciri, etc). however, i felt that the plot falters at times since [spoiler] the entire base game is just 1. finding a lead to ciri 2. doing something to convince person with lead to give information 3. finding out ciri has moved on 3. move on to next region 4. repeat  [/spoiler] In addition, i though the main villains of the game, the wild hunt hunt and eredin, were quite weak. the final encounter with them didnt really feel like what the game wanted to portray them as, especially the final fight. furthermore, while the quality of the side quests in the game is a major selling point to me, the sheer number of them really distracts from the main story. well, why dont i just ignore them then? the problem is that me, and most gamers, have OCD and want to get the most out of the game and thus proceed to clear their entire quest log before moving on to each region / checkpoint. at times, i do so many side quests that i forget wtf is happening in the main story . also, it feels weird and immersion breaking that the world is literally ending, and geralt is, for instance, stopping to help an old lady find her pan. there were moments where this was exhibited in the main quest line, such as finding and speaking to all of dandelion's girlfriends, etc, that seemed kinda pointless, tedious, and detracts from the tone of the main story. at the same time, the base game is what makes witcher 3. characters like yennefer and ciri are hard to top off, and regardless of how good the dlc's were, the world always felt empty without them present anymore. there are so many more things i want to say but im lazy atm and i cant think of them. imo, novigrad / oxenfurt > velen == white orchard> skellige == kaer morhenn base game. i really like the cities in the game. very cool very realistic.

now, onto my favorite part: hearts of stone. whereas i previously said the base game felt dragged on, the HOS dlc was a wild ride from start to finish. the way it was directed was amazing, and it had the darkest tone in the game. the lighting, design, camera angles, music, and characters really creates a memorable sense of creepiness. it also introduces the best villain of the series, and any game ive played, by far. the character is so well written and acted, despite of his simple looks, that its scary. no joke, i felt actual fear during his cutscenes. the over abundance of side quests wasnt really a problem in hos. what i like is that the story is so concentrated and thick. theres none of the stretched out filler that happens in the main game. everything makes sense -- its just a amazing experience filled with intrigue, mystery, fear, and sadness. olgeird and iris imo were more memorable than most characters from the main game. the second and third wish questlines were probably the best rpg quests that i've ever played in my career. ok yadadada

now lets talk about BaW, which i just finished last week after taking a ~2 year break. first of all, gah damn, is toussaint the most beautiful region in all of witcher. fuck. like after exploring this region, i literally cant go back to any of the other regions because they give me ptsd. like i revisited velen for five minutes and got tf back to toussaint even thought my ass like a level 50 witcher. BaW is the perfect goodbye to geralts story. the main quest is engaging (with some weak spots in the plot [spoiler] i honestly expected more behind syanna's motives, being the 'cintrian'. like i thought, anna hinted her sister was the cintrain. and i thought, like cool, the games just trying to throw me off. but it turns out she was right, and that was it. like, i thought there would be a higher power behind it or something [/spoiler]. for the first time thought, BaW's toussaint made me want to just ride around the world, not for the sake of completing a quest, but just to experience the scenery from point A to point B. also , the points of interest were more interesting, or at least had more of an incentive in BaW. in the main game, they felt very diluted, as if they were only there to fill the world. but in BaW, they were intertwined with certain quests, which made them more interesting. BaW should be the industry standard of how an expansion should be. it honestly had more content than most standalone games. but damn i cant stop thinking about the beauty of toussaint. it really got me caught up the their culture, their fashion, virtues, tipsiness, yadayadayada what am i even saying at the point. 

gameplay:
honestly the skill tree / combat in the game is not balanced at all, but it didnt matter much to me as the story made the game for me. however, some abilities, like whirl, just break the game for me. i remember hitting level 16, and i just gave up on putting skill into my combat altogether. basically i could just hold left click , quen, dodge, repeat, and slaughter whatever in my sight. the brokeness kinda ruins the many cool things combat tools the game throws at you, such all the different decoctions, bombs, skills, etc. honestly, i probably used like 4 diff decoctions max throughout the whole game. i just saw no purpose of using all that stuff when i could melt enemies in seconds with just fast attacks. this really broke the immersion in certain parts of the game, especially the eredin fight, where i killed him in like, 9 blows. 

also there is way too much shit in the game to loot. like i be straining my neck to get the smallest wooden crate in the corner of a peasants house. i be traveling to my man hattori / grandmaster crafter every time i wipe a bandit camp, and i probably spent hours on inventory management. it does indeed take away from the games immersion. and in the end, i probably never utilized 97% of the items i looted. but fuck, i still do it anyways. 

shi im running out of space ! base game 6.7/10 HOS 10/10 BaW 8.9/10
BYEBYE WITCHER ITS BEEN A JOURNEY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Honestly just incredible. Gameplay is solid, story is engaging and few bugs make for a genuinely enjoyable experience.
Fantastic Game!!!!! So Fun the story is in depth just amazing to play.. Super recommend.
excellent game, even better when you know the lore
Wouldn't mind a few rounds of cards

Everyone raves about how this game is so good. My expecations were met. The story knew how to reel me in, despite some minor bumps at the beginning. The combat is good enough to make me look forward to the next boss fight. Speaking of which, have a nice touch of difficulty to them. They're not dark souls level, but if you don't know how to work the game's mechanics, you won't kill them. Go buy the GOTY edition. The extra expansions are really good. But make sure to repair your armor before you make your big decision in the last leg of Blood and Wine.

Straight up the best game I've ever played, here's some of the good and bad I experienced.

PROS:
LONG game time with expansions, Story-rich, good combat system, lots of decision-making to affect the game from start to finish, AWESOME graphics, great music, miles of land to explore, a plethora of enemies to fight everywhere, great upgrade system where you can create many different custom character builds, lots of online support to help you on the path to name a few.

CONS:
Sometimes clunky and still has the occasional bug, 'Roach' often doesn't work properly (not popping up on map when called, not moving from a location, getting stuck on everything) and have to restart a save to fix it, the enemies you fight generally are just re-skins, can sometimes be repetitive as all RPG's are.

I must say, although I did experience some cons in this game, in no way whatsoever did it distract me, or take anything away from my gaming experience which was absolutely awesome. I'm on my 3rd playthrough now, and it still hasn't gotten old.
Great game, lots of side quests.

Mniej wiecej 5 lat minelo od kiedy przeszedlem Witcher 3. Prawde mowiac jest to jedna z bardzo nielicznych gier ktore kupilem w przedsprzedazy czego normalnie nie mam w zwyczaju robic. Niedawno postanowilem wrocic ponownie do gry i ponownie przyjrzec sie dzielu CDPR. Pomyslalem majac za soba wieksze doswiadczenie moze warto spojrzec jeszcze raz czego tak naprawde dotyczy cala ta gloryfikacja Wiedzmina. Wobec tego rozpoczalem przygode zupelnie od nowa i prawde mowiac juz po spedzeniu zaledwie kilkudziesieciu godzin w grze wiem juz dokladnie gdzie Witcher 3 ma swoje zalety a gdzie gre najzwyczajniej zaniedbano. Moze zaczne standardowo od pozytywow...

Pomimo tego iz graficzne wzornictwo wyraznie odbiegalo jakosciowo od przed premierowej prezentacji gra wciaz zaoferowala naprawde zdumiewajace widoki. Nie bylo to cudo techniki ale caloksztalt wyszedl naprawde imponujaco. Dzisiaj oryginalne krajobrazy niestety nie robia juz na mnie takiego wrazenia. Nie znaczy to ze gra wyglada zle! po prostu w porownaniu do mlodszych produkcji widac tutaj bardzo wyrazna roznice. Po kilku godzinach gry stwierdzilem ze moze poinstaluje szereg modow graficznych ktore powinny zmienic wizerunek gry. Powiem tak... Warto poswiecic czas na zmodyfikowanie gry oj warto i to BARDZO. Przepasc wzgledem oryginalu jest bowiem kolosalna. Naprawde nie sposob opisac jak diametralna poprawe wprowadzaja mody. Ostre jak brzytwa tekstury sa w stanie zawstydzic kazda dzisiejsza konkurencje.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1kb6-cdDMWg
To jednak nie wszystko. Gra nabiera innego wizerunku dopiero po zainstalowaniu odpowiedniego reshade'u a takze licznych innych modyfikacji takich jak mod na trawe cienie swiatla postacie niebo mgle a takze krew i przemoc. Bezposrednie porownanie tak graficznie zmodyfikowanej gry do jej oryginalnego stanu udowadnia wrecz o czym mowie. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0lfNYsfy7Zo
Dodam do tego tyle ze instalacja modow jest calkowicie bezplatna i wcale nie skomplikowana... pod warunkiem ze czyta sie dokladnie opis i proces instalacji(!). Wszystko dostepne pod [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/witcher3]TYM[/url] adresem.

O optymalizacji gry nie ma w zasadzie co mowic. Dzisiaj kazdy ma na tyle rozsadny sprzet ze gra na pewno bedzie elegancko smigac. Nie mniej jednak pamietam bardzo dokladnie ze w 2015 przechodzilem gre majac 2 GTX'y 660 w SLI (moc ~GTX'a 770) oraz i5 3570K. Ta konfiguracja w zupelnosci wystarczyla by gra na wysokich ustawieniach 1080p osiagala stabilne 50-60fps. Po jakims czasie wymienilem zestaw SLI na GTX'a 780 ktory w zupelnosci wyeliminowal spadki <60fps. 

Zdecydowanie najlepszym elementem gry to jej fabula a takze sam styl jej przedstawienia. Powiem szczerze ze majac za soba wszystkie czesci Assassins Creed'a bylem bardzo ciekawy czy moja krytyka wobec "dziel" Ubisoft'a jest pod tym wzgledem solidnie uzasadniona. Final byl taki iz sam prolog Wiedzmina spowodowal ze pojawily mi sie lzy w oczach. Tak fenomenalnym budowaniem intrygi moze sie poszczycic malo ktora gra. Bez watpienia Witcher 3 nalezy pod tym wzgledem do kategorii arcydziel. Ogromna role odgrywa tutaj fantastyczne skomponowanie dialogow ktore bardzo mocno kojarza mi sie z serialem 'The Wire' lub 'Gra o Tron'. Kwestie sa ponadto bogato okraszone w roznego rodzaju staropolskie wyrazenia oraz typowa gware. To w polaczeniu z bardzo dobrym voice acting'iem tworzy niesamowicie ciekawa wymiane zdan od ktorej ciezko sie oderwac. Sledzenie przygody i losow postaci w takiej postaci to cholernie wciagajaca przyjemnosc. 

Nie mozna tutaj zapomniec o pierwszorzednym soundtracku ktory wysmienicie tworzy atmosfere w tym opartym o tworczosc Sapkowskiego swiecie. Eksploracja pomimo tego ze jest wypelniona random-eventami dosc ubogo to mimo to wsparta jest milym dla ucha ambientem co w efekcie zapobiega nudzie. Natomiast samych utworow w soundtracku jest moim zdaniem za malo jak na gre takiej skali. Tak czy inaczej piekne melodie ze skrzypcami jako przewodni instrument wsparte cudownym wokalem niesamowicie dobrze wpadaja w ucho. Jakosc > ilosc oczywiscie. Dlatego tez ogolne odczucie strony dzwiekowej jest jaknajbardziej pozytywne i nie ma sie tutaj absolutnie czego czepiac.

W tym punkcie nastal ten moment gdzie jestem zmuszony przejsc do problemow z gra ktore niestety z biegiem czasu tylko sie mnozyly.
- Nielogiczny balans handlu w ktorym sprzedac mozemy unikatowa kose za doslownie grosze. Handlarz natomiast moze nam sprzedac bezuzyteczny kozik warty tysiace.
- Dlaczego bezuzyteczny? Poniewaz poza roslinkami artykulami rzemieslniczymi oraz kartami do gwinta nie warto kupowac czegokolwiek innego gdyz jest to najzwyczajniej "zlom".
- Skad wobec tego wsiasc uzyteczny sprzet? Ekslorujac swiat ze "?" otrzymamy az zanadto rynsztunku ktory kompletnie deklasuje to co oferuja handlarze.
- Zachowanie konia jest niesamowicie frustrujace. Poza niewygodnym sterowaniem kon z premedytacja po zejsciu z niego chowa sie do takiej "dziury" by maksymalnie utrudnic gre.
- Mozna go oczywiscie zawolac jednak czasami trwa to nawet 1min. Rumak najzwyczajniej nie chce do nas podejsc.
- Natomiast podczas walki wrecz odwrotnie celowo wchodzi pod kose.
- Utrudniajac walke w juz delikatnie niesprawnym poruszaniu sie postaci. Geralt notorycznie blokuje sie na roznego rodzaju smiesznych przeszkodach gdzie absolutnie nie powinno to miec miejsca.
- Dokladnie tosamo tyczy sie eksploracji gdzie czasami mozemy natknac sie na niewidzalna sciane lub most do ktorego trzeba 2-u krotnie brac rozped.
- Sa tez inne roznego rodzaju mniejsze mechaniczne problemy ktore moznabylo inaczej rozwiazac. Nie wyszczegolnie ich tutaj bo limit znakow mnie ogranicza.
- Jestem jednak zmuszony napisac tutaj ze gra zawiera pewien powazny problem. W pewnym momencie gry dotrzemy do punktu w ktorym nalezy popchnac glowna fabule dalej. Jednak w miedzyczasie mamy jeszcze >10 innych zadan do wykonania. Jesli zdecydujemy sie na wykonanie wpierw zadan pobocznych (gdyz jestesmy aktualnie na pasujacym levelu) dochodzi do fundamentalnego problemu w koncepcji gry. Albowiem zadanie Geralta skupia sie na znalezieniu Ciri a nie zajmowaniem sie pierdolami wiesniakow. W obliczu tego glowny watek gry zupelnie traci swoj sens poniewaz Geralt przedklada "bzdury" nad poszukiwania swojej "corki".
- Ktos moze jednak powiedziec ze "nikt cie nie zmusza robic side-questow" czyli podchodzimy do gry odwrotnie tzn. skupiamy sie stricte na szukaniu ciri zostawiajac pozostale zadania na pozniej. W tej sytuacji dochodzi niestety do powaznego problemu w mechanice gry. Sprawa wyglada tak ze Witcher 3 nie oferuje skalowania levelu zadania/wrogow wzgledem aktualnego levelu gracza. Efekt tego jest taki ze "wracajac pozniej" do "starego" questu mozemy byc nawet 2-krotnie silniejsi od wrogow. To z kolei powaznie koliduje z glownym zalozeniem poziomu trudnosci ktory w tej konkretnej sytuacji w zasadzie przestal istniec.
- Inna idiotyczna sprawa spotkala mnie w zadaniu z kowalem Hattori. W skrocie... Przyjalem zadanie po dotarciu do Novigradu bedac na odpowiednim sugerowanym levelu. Kowal chce rozwiazac pewien problem na co sie godze. Udajemy sie do dokow gdzie kowal juz na nas czeka. Przede mna walka z wrogami o niemmal 15 leveli wyzej niz poziom mojej postaci. GG. Gdybym wiedzial ze kontynuacja tego zadania skaluje sie na 24 level to w ogole bym tego zadania nie ruszal. Niestety nie wiedzialem i mam teraz bezuzytecznego(!) kowala stojacego dniami i nocami w porcie. Bez sensu...

Mimo wszystko opisane wyzej problemy nie sa moim zdaniem na tyle drastyczne by zniechecic lub calkowicie uniemozliwic zabawe. Gra ma fenomenalnie rewelacyjne budowanie fabuly ktore urzeka od calkiem pierwszych minut gry jak rowniez ma swoje irytujace a czasami frustrujace mankamenty. Da sie je na szczescie przebolec bez wyrywania sobie wlosow. Za gre zaplacilem jakos niecale 50e ok. 10 miesiecy przed premiera i moge szczerze powiedziec ze byly to jedne z najlepiej wydanych pieniedzy na gre komputerowa.
pretty nice story and good gameplay,you could love it

think like an actual witcher
that's my advice playing this game, you wont regret it

Die The Witcher Reihe ist ein tolles Universum fÃ¼r Leute, die auf Fantasy stehen, mit dem Anspruch irgendwie realistisch zu sein. Damit meine ich, das was es in The Witcher gibt - Hexer, Zauberinnen, Monster, Zwerge, Elfen, das basiert alles mehr oder weniger auf MÃ¤rchen, die aber weiter ausgestrickt wurden und das ganze wird dann noch etwas dunkler dargestellt. Dies ist spielerisch ein tolles Erlebnis. Menschen werden hier meist von ihren schlechtesten Seiten gezeigt, die Elfen, einst ein stolzes Volk, sind heute aber kaum mehr als Terroristen (in der Sicht der Menschen) und die Zwerge....nunja die Zwerge sind eben sie selbst. Rassismus ist im Spiel ein prÃ¤sentes Thema - Stichwort Anderlinge.
Kommen wir mal zum Ende:
The Witcher 3 ist spielerisch eine tolle Erfahrung und sehr immersiv. Toller Soundtrack tolle Welt. Wer die VorgÃ¤ngerteile noch nicht gespielt hat, sollte es nachholen. The Witcher 1 habe ich persÃ¶nlich auf dem leichtesten Schwierigkeitsgrad einmal durchgespielt, weil das Gameplaytechnisch nicht sooo gut war, aber fÃ¼r die Story sollte man es einmal gespielt haben. The Witcher 2 hingegen ist ein absoluter Pflichtitel. Der vorherige Teil macht sogar einiges besser, als sein Nachfolger und in einigen wenigen Punkten, wie Set Pieces und World Design, schlÃ¤gt es The Witcher 3 deutlich.

Gameplay:
Swordplay worked similarly to The Witcher 2, however with some slight differences. You can move around a lot more during combat in The Witcher 3. Pressing alt to dodge made for responsive combat, instead of pressing space to do the laziest roll in The Witcher 2.

Signs have some slight differences. Aard (the sign to push people back) still does that, but The Witcher 2 started it out with only targeting one enemy. The Witcher 3 does what The Witcher 1 does, and creates an arc in front of you so that all enemies within that arc will likely fall over.

Igni (the sign to cause fire damage) will still set opponents on fire. However, once again, The Witcher 2 made it so that it would only target one opponent. The Witcher 3, similarly to The Witcher 1, would create an arc that would affect all enemies. I used this sign the most, and enjoyed the alt-fire mode. You could have a flamethrower coming out of your hand. I have not experimented with other alt-fire signs, but they certainly exist.

Quen (the sign to create a shield) works almost exactly as it did in The Witcher 2. However, similarly to The Witcher 1, the shield has a health bar. The Witcher 2 gives Quen a duration on how long it will last, but can also cause opponents to take damage for attacking. Using perk points in The Witcher 3, you can still do that.

Axii (the sign to hypnotise) is slightly different from The Witcher 2. I can't say much about The Witcher 1, as I never really used it in the original game. At least not as far as I remember. The Witcher 2 immediately gave it the ability to take control of an enemy, but The Witcher 3 allows you to do that through perk points. From the start, you can confuse enemies and get an easy few hits on them with your swords.

Yrden (the sign to slow down enemies) does the exact same thing as The Witcher 2, and (I guess) the same thing as The Witcher 1. It creates an area around you that causes enemies to slow down significantly. This became especially helpful since The Witcher 2 as Spectres would struggle within Yrden. Again, I used this sparingly, and I can't say much about it.

The storytelling in the game is either really good, or not the best. The story itself (I'll avoid as many spoilers as possible) gives you these flashbacks from other people's memories. Not your own. I don't mind if Geralt has flashbacks of people he knew ages ago, but he shouldn't be able to see the flashbacks of other people. It took all of the tension out of finding who we're looking for throughout the story, and the actual finding of them feels as if it's undeserved. Especially during the introduction, in White Orchard. You're tracking an individual only for them to find you and realise they're very close by anyway. Overall, though, the story was fun to play through.

The Witcher Contracts is where the really amazing storytelling comes into play. Instead of them being Fetch Quests (I'm looking at you, Witcher 1 and 2) you actually have a story to follow. The people surrounding the story are often unreliable, and you must figure out their motives. Often you'll wind up mediating between a human and a spectre, figuring out what your correct cause of action is. Often your decisions may even lead to deaths of innocent people, decisions that will weigh on you forever.

You will also get a guide regarding which level to be at to complete certain quests. I just completed the quests in the order of levels, from lowest to highest. This caused my playthrough to be 55 hours long altogether. For comparison, The Witcher 1 claims to be between 40-45 hours, and yet I got 35 hours out of it. The Witcher 2 took less time to complete, taking 24 hours in total. There's still much to do, many contracts and side-quests to get on with. I have my hands full should I want to continue.

The levelling system is much different to the previous games. In The Witcher 1 and 2, you unlock perks that will stay with you throughout the game. In The Witcher 3, however, you can only have up to 12 perks at a time. You can have 4 mutagens at a time also. The mutagens and the perks bond together. If you combine three green perks with a green mutagen, you will multiply the power of the mutagen by four times the original amount. If you have no green perks but you use a green mutagen, that green mutagen will only have its regular stats. Each perk you bind to a mutagen increases the multiplier, forcing you to organise how your perks are set out in the menu.

If you have played since The Witcher 1, you can expect to see the characters you met throughout each game in The Witcher 3. For example, at the start of The Witcher 2 I met a Temerian Blue Stripes Commando who became a good friend. I met them again in The Witcher 3, and they were wonderful company.
Sadly this game can be buggy at times. Often I'd wind up not being able to call my horse even though I should be able to. Or my horse would not gallop, even though I'm in the middle of a field in Velen. There was this one time that I was on Skellige, and I climbed a mountain with my horse at full speed. The horse suddenly thought it was on level ground, and its head and front of its body were all buried in the mountain and the back was in the air. I was still climbing at a rapid pace and I couldn't help but laugh.

Les - :

Great open world RPG. I got bored of the dialogue after some time and started skipping it. It is not a perfect game and still has a lot of bugs. What I mean to say is that it is a AAA title at the end of the day. And no AAA game is perfect. These games try to mimic reality and can never succeed fully. But they do tell a good story. I personally didn't feel that connected to the story(idk why), but still it was a good game. Combat was good. The world looks also pretty good. I recommend it. BUT IT IS NOT PERFECT. 

You might ask what is a perfect game?
Answer- Celeste
One of the best looking RPG's I've played. Could be better? yes, but the story and the landscapes are quite good, at times great, and with the secret sauce of the original books.

Quick disclaimer. I have more bad to say about this game than good, buuuuut despite all the criticism it is a great game and a must buy IF it is on sale. DO NOT pay full price for this. The idea that in 2015 people paid 60 dollars for this is truly upsetting. 

Pros
- Interesting world based on the Witcher Novels with lots to explore.
- Tons of side quests that are actually more fun than the main quest.
- Main characters have a ton of personality. 
- Side Characters are super interesting and make you want to learn more about their lives and the world of Witcher.
- The soundtrack is cool, and the music in the open world is great! Walking by bards is a treat!

Cons
- Playing the game suuuuuucks. Fighting monsters literally felt like a chore and a distraction from story. 
- The controls are super clunky. Imagine that someone poured a bunch of syrup on your joystick. 
- Combat is repetitive and hard due to the bad controls. Easy difficulty is preferable, as combat is not the games forte.
- The loot button is the same button as sprint, so you will often overshoot the thing you are trying to loot. 
- There is too much loot, and you will constantly get new gear that is slightly better than the old stuff. 
- On top of there being too much gear, all of that gear has durability and is very annoying to manage. 
- You have a carry capacity, and always too much loot to hold, so you are constantly overburdened. 
- There is a complex crafting system! That you will literally never need to use since the game will give you good gear.
- You can only fast travel from a fast travel point. Meaning if you are in the middle of nowhere you have to walk to one!
- The game is really starting to show it's age. 
- Cutscenes in this game look worse than the open world, and they pop up constantly. 
- Voice acting volume is constantly changing between cutscenes, open world, and loading screens. 
- Tons of bugs, some that stop you from being able to do quests. 
- The main story is a bit dull after you meet up with Ciri. Finding her is the good part of the game. 

Now I know what you are thinking, why should I get this game if there are so many problems with it? It's because the world and it's inhabitants are so interesting and fun to interact with, that it negates all of the problems with the game. Especially when the game is on sale, it's honestly a steal to get this game for 10 bucks. The game is at it's best when you view it as an interactive story book, where you have to swing your sword around sometimes. If this game didn't have a super easy mode, I don't think I could suggest it. 

 I will say though there are a few mods that are a must get if you buy this game. Both of them are on NexusMods for free and I'll link them below. The first lets you fast travel whenever you want, the second gets rid of carry capacity, and the third gets rid of weapon durability. 

1. Fast Travel: https://www.nexusmods.com/witcher3/mods/324
2. Carry Capacity:  https://www.nexusmods.com/witcher3/mods/342
3. Weapon Durability: https://www.nexusmods.com/witcher3/mods/3
good game, get DLC, is good

Classic game. I played over 100 hours on my XBox and couldn't resist buying it for the PC after I built a gaming PC. It's my favorite game of all time and it is even better on the second play through.

Wonderful game. Well made, pretty polished (except the horse physics), and great stories. 

Like most open-world games the only criticism I'd have is the world feels 'empty' and the quests feel repetitive after a while. I found myself skipping cut-scenes more and more about halfway through. Maybe if there were more 'choices' and interactivity in the dialogue I would've felt more invested. Still, the main quests of the base and DLCs were wonderfully done.

I've poured so many hours of my life into The Witcher 3 and I still can't get enough. I've played this game on the Xbox, the Switch, and now on the PC. 

Geralt of Rivia and his grand adventures take you through, quite literally, hell and back in this game. The combat mechanics can be somewhat lacking at times and repetitive, you'll quickly learn how important it is to level up Geralt and unlock skills to ease the pain of redundancy of the ever recurring battles that he faces. At the beginning, it can be seem like a daunting task to learn about the sword techniques and the use of Signs but eventually you will get the hang of it and rely on both of them to get you through each day.

As for the graphics, the scenery in the masterfully crafted game is absolutely incredible. It's easy to stand at the top of a mountain or a castle and just look around to take in the sights. The trees, the rivers/creeks, the lakes, even the little forest critters are beautiful. The sounds that go with the imagery are just as amazing, it makes you feel like you are there with Geralt.

Another really fascinating and enjoyable part of this game is the crafting and the alchemy. I love that it's not as easy as just going to a merchant and buying whatever you need and then going back to your quest. You have to travel out to the wilderness and search for herbs or pieces of equipment to better your gear and potions. It's a really immersive game and that takes up so much time but I do find it to be a lot of fun, like a treasure hunt. 

Lastly, the story! Do not ever skip the cut scenes! The story in this game is so detailed and keeps you hooked. Another interesting part of this game is that every choice you make impacts the outcome of a lot the quests so that's partly the reason why you should pay attention to the cut scenes as well.

I love this game and I try to convince as many people as I can to play it just so they can experience it firsthand like I did all those years ago. I've played it many times and it's still my favorite game!

I've returned to this game multiple times over the years and each time I've found something new to love about this game. Originally it was the story on the PS4 but now that I'm on PC, I've fallen in love with the look and how well the game plays. This game was meant to be played at 60+ fps IMO. On top of that, I've gotten into modding and the game looks even better with a few upgrades and HUD changes. Probably my favorite game released in the last 10 years easily.

I initially couldn't get in to the game, feeling a little bit overwhelmed with the different systems and not having an existing love for the franchise.

After watching the Witcher TV show it gave me the stamina to push through these initial road blocks and has become one of the best RPGs I've played and I'd strongly recommend persevering!

Very fun RPG. A good amount of variety and depth to the main quests, with tons of enjoyable side quests and a large, fleshed-out open world. I was pleasantly surprised by how much content there is in the game and by the variety of different monsters the player faces. This was my introduction to the Witcher franchise and have enjoyed the world of the game- although clearly fictionalized, I personally like how the game draws from aspects of medieval history and folklore.

Amazing game once you get the hang of it.  Choices can have subtle, yet long lasting ramifications.  My only complaint is leveling.  You get past 30 and start fighting level 30 thieves and wolves.  Slightly breaks immersion.  Other than that, top notch game, easily takes near 80 hours to complete the main quest if you aren't racing.  Side stories are deep and worth exploring.

Ğ¥ÑƒĞ¹ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ÑĞ» ĞºĞ°Ğº ÑĞºĞ°Ğ»Ğ° (Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€Ğ²ÑƒÑ Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ñ€ĞµÑ‡Ñƒ Ñ Ğ³ÑƒĞ»ÑĞ¼Ğ¸)

After 200 hours, what can I say about this game? Such a remarkable, ambitious achievement of an RPG world that it really hasn't aged much at all. Still an absolute pleasure to explore and still home to some of the best writing and characters the genre's ever seen. For example when pluck an innocuous-sounding bounty from a village notice board, you never ever really know what kind of wild story you're about to get yourself tangled up in. Almost every quest feels weighty, accurate and worthwhile, with memorable stories inspired by some of the very strangest cuts from depths of Eastern European folklore(Thanks Andrzej Sapkowski).
