The game is good in general terms. The history, music, graphic, and so is good.

However the underlying RPG system is very broken. Let me give you two examples:

[b]  - The inventory system. [/b] 

There is master craftman Hattori, leyend of leyends, capable of making swords to be wielded by a god and you need to pass an entire quest so he is able to do so. He make you the sword, and then a random peasant in the other side of the map have swords to sell at double the level for the same price. What?

Same goes for every single magic,relic, and leyendery item that you find. The stupid inventory level system is awful in every game that uses it. Specially when you have a hand axe that a monkey would be able to wield, but because you are not level 22 yet you are unable to even grab it. It doesn't make any sense and totally break any immersion of the game.

[b] - The enemy level system. [/b]

Pretty much the same issue. You have nekkers and bandits level 4 that are basically the lowest level enemies in the game, and also nekkers and bandits level 30 that are near impossible to kill even for a regular Witcher. Like a random human Nilgardian soldier have higher level, than a cyclop that takes several hours to level up in order to be able to kill it. What are you hiring a Witcher for anyway then?

Both problems above you can find it in many games, as for example Borderlands to mention one. Terraria does this very well. You can use anything you find, but boy, you are in trouble to get the ingredients or kill the monsters in order to adquire everything.

[b]  - The XP system. [/b] 

If you are too high level for the mission you barely get any XP, but it doesn't happen the other way around. I have pass missions 10 levels above me, with the red skull telling me that this is suicide, and barely got 50xp which is the same xp you get for blowing up a random monster nest.

There is no consistency, and what is worse, you end up just grinding for leveling up.

[b]  - The economy system. [/b] 

Again, it doesn't make sense be a Witcher in this universe, when just by selling random crap to merchants give you better pay that putting your life in the line for killing an abobination from hell. Sure; this sword that you want to sell me, that is going to be updated anyway 5 hours from now, is worth the same that killing the monster that is eating all the children of the village alive. What=??

So if you want a proper RPG, pass this game. If you just want an ARPG with no deep into it, sure, the game is fun for what it is. Just understand what you are getting.

How one of my friend have said: It is easily the best game of the decade - and I agree! I have never been a fan of RPG games but it change after playing this masterpiece. If you combine story, gameplay, graphics / visuals / effects, characters (NPCs), options you can choose from, more endings - depens on your reaction in certain part of the story, missions, combat, crafting and you have the best game created so far. This is the best game you can get even in 2020. Try it and you will not regret playing it.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt gehÃ¶rt definitiv zu den besten Spielen, die ich jemals gespielt habe: Alleine die Hauptstory hat Ã¼ber 80 Stunden Spielmaterial geliefert, aktuell bin ich bei Ã¼ber 110 Stunden und habe noch den ersten DLC "Hearts of Stone" abgeschlossen und gerade mal den zweiten DLC "Blood and Wine" angefangen. Dazu gibt es noch unglaublich viele Nebenquests, unentdeckte Orte usw. aus dem Basisspiel, welche ich noch nicht entdeckt habe. Man kann also locker 200 Stunden in einen Spielstand investieren und langweilig wird es auch nie, eine dicke Empfehlung von mri!

Wow....

What an experience.  I can't even begin to describe how much I enjoyed this game.  I originally owned it on PS4 and put hundreds of hours in over several different files, but never got anywhere near beating it due to getting distracted by the sprawling landscape, massive to do list, and amazing lore.  When I got my PC, I was determined to get through it.  After near 100 hours, I finally did it.  While I did stray at times to enjoy side missions, I made sure to power through the story.  I put 12+ hours often into this game.  Completely hooked from start to finish, and I still have so much yet to do.  It yet has gotten bland for me. 

Aesthetically, the game is gorgeous.  The colors are bright and vibrant, the character models are stunning, and the views are breath taking.  I often found myself just spending time staring out at the mountains or the sea just appreciating the detail.  

The game mechanics and controls are flawless.  Other than remapping the lock button to one of my mouse buttons, it was blissful to control.  Whether it be combat, adventure, even navigating menus and speech options, it was insanely fluid and I never found myself frustrated or confused about the layout of the controls.  

The game has a perfect blend of adventure and combat, neither get stale.  The countless different ways to maim, cripple, burn, amputate, decapitate, or eviscerate your enemies is always satisfying.  The adventuring never falls into the infinite fetch quest trap that many open world games like this do.  Even when there are fetch quests, it is more than a simple go to A to get B.  You have to actually think and pay attention to find what you are looking for.  Plus, I never get tired finding new Wtcher sets to make Geralt look more bad ass as he kicks ass.  

The music.  Not much to say about it other than the soundtrack is perfect.  It is so fitting with the era this series is based off of, and they pull it off so well.  The instrumentation is perfect, and often the soundtrack will be seen being played by street musicians or bands within the Inns and taverns you visit.  It blends so well you may not even notice it, but guarantee you will catch yourself whistling along eventually.

I could go on and on about everything I love about this game, but I will end it with the story.  Simply put.  It is one of the most immersive experiences in story telling I have ever had.   The hundreds maybe thousands of books sprawling with lore, the emotional connects you will have with multiple characters, it makes you feel as though you are there.  You will be angry with the characters, cry with them, and laugh with them.  I felt like I was part of Geralt of Rivia's story.   

If you live under a rock and have not played this game, BUY IT.  PLAY IT.  LOVE IT.

Hands down my favorite single-player campaign game (so far). I have many more games on the back-burner, but I really enjoy the story, characters, humor, and choices you get to make in this game.
The cut-scenes are great, occasionally the sounds from the characters are weird and the volumes can be a bit off, but the stories are very well thought out.
The fighting controls are great for the controller. Some other games force you to spam click to run and other things, but I like that you can choose to auto-sprint when holding a button down.
I have not really played many rpg's before, but I am really getting into designing a great build out with the armor, weapons choices, and crafting magic. 
Sometimes after doing a few extra side quests I can find my character getting too strong compared to enemies, even on Death March. Though a couple of bosses/characters have kicked my butt even with trying specific tactics. Overall, the game keeps showing new sides, different adventures, and even forces you to make tough choices.
Idk why everyone likes this game.

Only con that comes to my mind: Moving with Roach is sometimes total hell but she is the biggest meme in this game anyways.

I recommend this game because it's a major milestone in open worlds, but I actually don't like it as much as most people do. I'll just hit 4 points:
-Many of your choices from The Witcher 2 don't carry over, especially if you picked Iorveth's path. Iorveth and Saskia are nowhere to be found. I think the devs built this game for Roche's path, and then ran out of time before adding Iorveth's.
-Even though the world is huge, most if it is either empty space, copy-and-pasted monster nests, or locked buildings that are empty and just meant to create the facade of a large civilization.
-Crafting is pointless except for the absolute best weapons/armor. That's because equipment scales by level. So if you spend hours collecting materials to craft a great sword at level 20, after one quest you'll hit level 21 and the sword will be useless.
-Even though you can vary your playstyle, only one playstyle will work well in NG+. That's because some playstyles--like signs--don't scale nearly as well as others from level to level. So a lot of your personal playstyle preferences get tossed aside.

Una obra de arte dentro de los juegos de rol. Encarnamos al brujo Geralt de Rivia, cuyas hazaÃ±as, narradas por el bardo Jaskier, debemos llevar a cabo. Para ello, debemos ganar dinero y experiencia para adquirir y mejorar habilidades y equipamiento, a travÃ©s de la bÃºsqueda de tesoros y mediante contratos solo aptos para brujos. Las decisiones que tomamos alteran fuertemente el camino de la historia, haciendo al juego Ãºnico para cada persona.  
Lo bueno: La historia, la mecÃ¡nica de los combates, la profundidad de los diÃ¡logos, los personajes.
Lo malo: SÃ³lo es posible jugar como el brujo, por lo que no hay mucha libertad a la hora de darle forma al personaje con el que jugamos.

This is the kind of game that leaves you sitting there, after 120 hours. Saying 'What do I do with my life now?' You become so immersed in the world and the characters, that it becomes difficult to go back to reality. I've played my fair share of RPG's, but none have had a real emotional impact on me. Until, I played The Witcher 3. This game will put you through every possible emotion, and take your morals for a spin too. If you're looking for an action packed game, with incredible stories to tell. Or a game that blurs the line between good and evil, with morally grey choices. Then The Witcher 3 is for you.

To be honest.. probably best game I've ever played. Everything is awesome, as I would imagine perfect modern RPG game. Plenty of places to explore, a lot of interesting and unique locations with unique loot. A massive amount of different enemies with their own moveset.
Story is perfect. I also played 2 previous games and it all blends perfectly. I don't wanna spoil it because I think everyone should play this game for himself and see. 
A lot of dialoque choices that lead to it's own end. You can make really big choices, sometimes even saving the whole villages, towns or society and revert the outcome of war.
My first 100% playthrough took me approximately 160 hours, that says the game is really big and you will always have something to do... Yes, you can finish it in 50 hours, but why would you do it? People should really pay attention to all the details hidden across the map, enjoy the landscape, try to find new and unique builds etc.
As I said, best game I've ever played! Let's see if new decade changes anything, but I doubt it! ;)
Recently started my 2nd playthrough on the highest difficulty and hit 200hrs mark. And I won't stop there. I think at one point I will even hit 1000hrs mark, because this game can be played in soo many different ways.

First game ever I would rate 10/10. There is really nothing to complain on.

One of the best games i've ever played.

I haven't played many 3rd player games, so at first the mechanics were a little strange to get used to; however, once used to them the game was quite enjoyable. 

I, like other players, found myself addicted to side quests, gwent, horse racing, and boxing... Ciri can handle herself - I have cards to play, gwent specifically.

Graphics are great (especially for a game released 5 years ago) and the open world / choose your own destiny is fantastic.

The Witcher 3 is as dense and deep as the other two games in the series in terms of RPG mechanics, and the overwhelmingly massive open-world environment has at once made that depth more intimidating, and in the long run, more rewarding. Itâ€™s difficult to express just how huge and open this world is: verdant, rolling fields liberally dotted with swaying foliage of every shape and size fill the space between loosely connected, ramshackle townships where people struggle to scrape by. A full day/night cycle and dynamic weather pull it all together, cementing The Witcher 3â€™s landscape as one of the most authentic-feeling open worlds Iâ€™ve ever seen. A handy minimap points you where you want to go, which might seem like a crutch, but honestly, without it, Iâ€™d have been hopelessly lost. That a world this size still feels so purposeful, and full of things to do is quite an achievement.

Without a doubt the most boring trite I have ever played in my life. On a technical level it's a good game, it runs well, it's pretty and there is clearly a lot of love put into the game. However, the game itself is absolutely mind-numbing. 

The gameplay is very similar to the 'Batman: Arkham' games with combos and gadgets, but unlike the Arkham games the Witcher 3's combat is not only easy and hilariously abusable - its also boring. The game gives you the tools to make combat irrelevant in the form of signs, oils and decoctions: Igni does a ludicrous amount of damage, Quen makes you functionally invincible if you have a brain, decoctions buff you to absurd degrees and  oils skyrocket your damage even further. Raising the difficulty makes no appreciable difference, enemies simply have more health and damage which just forces you to rely more on the trivialising signs and oils. Bosses are similarly meaningless; just bigger enemies to annihilate with said tools. The only time the game is difficult is when enemies swarm you and lunge at you from off-screen to one-shot you but it doesn't matter because I have quen and I'm fucking invincible. 

"Just don't use signs or oils if they make the game so easy," I hear you say from your highchair. Let's just ignore that doing so removes half the game and go with it, and well now suddenly you just added 50 extra hours to the gameplay because enemies now have one million health. If you have even the slightest amount of skill in any video game with a functioning combat system you wont need oils and are probably saving time by not wandering around for hours picking up plants. None of this would be a problem if it wasn't all so fucking boring, the combat can be easy if its fun but it isn't. It's clunky, it's slow. It is boring.


Maybe the puzzles are really good? Sadly, there are no puzzles in Witcher 3. Despite what you may think, walking into a room and turning on [strike]detective-vision[/strike] Witcher-sense and hunting for pixels is not a puzzle, you are not solving anything by following a bread crumb trail, you are not solving anything by listening to Geralt tell you what to do and you are not solving anything by hunting glowing pixels until you are to allowed to leave. "Puzzles" in Witcher are time-wasters to make people think that they are actually solving shit when really you're just walking around in circles, listening to boring dialogue and clicking on glowing buttons like a conditioned ape. Now that I think about it... puzzles in Witcher are very similar to the puzzles in Dora the Explorer.


Well it is a story based game, so surely the story is good. To be honest I never finished the story, I had better things to do with my time run than between 50 npcs to have boring conversations about the lives of paper-thin, predictable carcitures. As to how far i got in the story itself, I stopped playing a few hours after the 'Bloody Baron' questline. Lets go over the 'Bloody Baron' questline. (Spoiler warning) It is a story that covers the tragedy of a poor baron who beats his wife and child to within an inch of their lives and now feels sad that they left him :'(. Your role in this is that he knows your estranged god-like super-soldier adopted daughter that you, for whatever reason, are worried about and he has knowledge of her whereabouts so now are forced to do several hours of soul crushingly boring I-Spy puzzles and meaningless dialogue with a wife beater you're a supposed to feel sorry for. People often point to this part of the game as being an excellent story with great characters which may be true if you have never engaged in any media beyond spongebob. However this is supposed to be an adult story for adult brains which is funny considering the gameplay until this point treats you as if you are 6 years old. It's kinda concerning, especially when you consider that most of the target audience for this game aren't going to be able to pick up on any of the themes it almost conveys or take it in the completely wrong direction since gamers arent known for their respect for women. Thankfully the quest ends and you are given your precious information about how your princess is in another castle which from what i am told is basically how the rest of the game goes. I was not able to get much deeper information about the rest of the story as anyone else I know fails to remember anything beyond brief moments and/or the dreams they had falling asleep while playing. If you're crying from your crib while reading my review, answer this; do YOU remember the story? 


What it all really comes down to is that Witcher 3 is a babys-first RPG masquerading as something more. Its combat is clunky, unfun and abusable, its story is shallow and predictable, the RPG elements are limited to being Geralt and worst of all, in a medium with one major goal, The Witcher 3 is boring. Despite all that I have said, I understand that enjoyment is subjective and you're allowed to enjoy The Witcher 3. Jesus, it can even be your favourite game for all I care. However, quality is objective and Witcher 3 is objectively a bad game and the people who treat it like some incredible masterpiece that changed the landscape of video games are just wrong. When Dark Souls came out it was so beloved that it inspired an entire genre known as 'Souls-likes' some of which went on to great success such as: Star-Wars Fallen Order and Nioh. Even other nerd games like Hollow Knight are heavily inspired by Dark Souls. I struggle to find refrences or any game made in The Witchers image, 6 years since this game came out, and yet no one bothers to make a copycat game or anything like it. Let me repeat - it is not because the game is too perfect to imitate, but because anyone with understanding of video games knows that not only is it a shit game and isn't worth replicating, but no game developer wants to be in crunch time for two years to make endless mediocre quests with the same writing level as Skyrim. 


If you're looking for an RPG experience that isnt a complete waste of time I suggest the following:

Misc: Horizon Zero Dawn, Red Dead Redemption 2, Final Fantasy 7 (I hear the remake is good), Vampyre the masquerade bloodlines (combat is crap but the story is vast), Bioshock 1 (not much of RPG but one of the best stories in video gaming), Undertale (despite the memes it is legitimately a good game with a lot of heart)

Sci-fi: Fallout New Vegas, Mass Effect 1-3,  Deus Ex Human Revolution, Deus Ex Mankind Divided, the original Deus Ex (2000) is a legitimate masterpiece but it's like 20 years old and I wouldn't recommend it unless you are prepared for something so outdated

Fantasy: Dragon Age, Skyrim (much like Witcher it's an extremely entry level RPG but even though it's shit it's at least fun), Monster Hunter World (stories on the low end but combat-wise it's a lot of fun) DARK SOULS 1-3 (I am biased in this as it is my favourite game but it does something Witcher 3 never does... let go of your hand)

Excellent graphics, engaging storyline and so many side quests.

It took me several years to finish the main story, I'd always get pulled off to do one thing or another, then lose interest. But I'd always come back.

The Witcher. Loved this game was something new and pretty different from all the RPG's I have played in the past.
Assassin of Kings. This actually disappointed me a lot. I just couldn't engage with the story. The visual looked and feel felt totally over saturated like an 80's American TV show. I finished it but I really just ran through the campaign played the Roach path and nothing more.
Wild Hunt. Trumps the lot. This game is a master piece and might just be my favourite ever RPG. At first I found the visual style again a little jarring. The light and dark of sunshine and clouds seemed a little too abrupt for me. However I soon got over that once the story kicked into gear. The Characters are great and even the filler is entertaining. Just playing Gwent and being a jobbing Witcher is a lot of fun. Now 99 hours in and nearing the end of the Blood and Wine expansion I can say that everybody should play this game. Other developers should take note of the great story and characters. I have never read any of the books but I assume we all have Andrzej Sapkowski to thank for giving CD Project Red these great characters to work with.

Let's hope this is not the last game we see from them in the Witcherverse as it would be really nice to follow Ciri on some adventures. She is definitely my highlight of the game.

The Witcher 3 is an absolute top quality open world fantasy RPG filled with rich characters and a vast beautiful world to explore. Witcher 3 packs countless hours of game play through its seemingly endless side quests and thourough DLC campaigns. The Witcher series of games is a fantastic delve into the fantasy/RPG genre and has an equally fantastic book series to back it up.

Gameplay aside, the depth of Witcher stories is as intricate as Nietzsche combined with fluidity of Shakespeare. You will experience emotional rollercoaster of everything the vile human nature has produced in its glorious and bloody history, from love and romance, to the most horrifying aberrations of sadism and cruelty. Make sure you are emotionally stable, otherwise laughter and tears are guaranteed.

Game is so far living up to all the hype.  I originally started playing Witcher 1 made it a little ways.  But then I started hearing the this one is so great just go ahead and play it first.  So I dropped 1 and started this one.  Loving it.  Just need more time to play.
Ã© bem legal bem bacana gostei bastante

When the Witcher 1 came out, I thought the gameplay was.. Acceptable, whereas the story was somewhat confusing and finally I found the setting to be particularly good. 
The Witcher 2 suffered from some of the same issues that the Witcher 1 had - the game was a drag in many ways, but significantly better gameplay wise, though I'm not going to lie - I hated the locations the game took place in. 

The witcher 3 made all the suffering from the previous games worth it. It remains one of my favorite games. 
However, that said, I will not play this game without mods. 
I am not a fan of the game's tendency to reward you with "leveled" items, but fortunately there are mods that fix that.
my favourite game of all time

I enjoy games that tell a story, and Witcher 3 does not disappoint! When I spend money on a game, I spend countless hours chasing down every possible quest, and this game gave a lot of side quests to chase. All told, it took me 136 hours to pour through all of them.  A few were buggy and couldn't be completed, but all told -- this game was great fun. 4 stars, do recommend!

after finally sitting down for this game I must say that this is one of the most story rich and beautiful games out there.
I have played a lot but this just stands out of the crowed.
combat is good and goes in the little detail that most games don't, planning every move you make.

The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt is a game that will appeal to everyone. There you will find an open world, great story and lots of quests. Here you can kill monsters, use signs, make decisions in many situations and much more. Cd projekt red did a good job of creating this game.

Probably won't be a popular opinion, and I'm not super far into it, but I can't recommend this. But if fetch quests that you can't complete until you complete three other nested fetch quests first, and then another one when you thought you were finally done, along with lots of following NPCs around (who are faster than your walking speed, and slower than your running speed -- and they take you way far away, and then you just have to go back -- all the while making sure nothing happens to the precious NPC), then maybe this is your game. The first Witcher game was better,  and I didn't bother to finish that one, either.

Phenomenal.  Nothing more needs to be said that hasn't already been said.  I spent nearly the entirety of my Christmas holidays with lockdown playing and completing this top to bottom and honestly it was one of the best times in gaming I've ever had.
The graphics even five years on are spectacular.  The world building is amazing.  The RPG elements are well done, combat is fluid and involving, and the stories and quests you stumble upon as you traverse this huge, war-ravished world are excellently written with plenty of choice.  It truly is a masterpiece and deserves all the praise it gets.

Few games live up to the hype surrounding them. I didn't think that I'd be able to jump into the Witcher 3 so easily as its the first one I've played, but it had me hooked from the moment I started. Great art cutscenes, a gripping story, and different weaknesses of enemies have kept it fresh so far even after several hours of gameplay.

Simply put: This is the best RPG I have ever played and I can see myself coming back to it over and over again. Now bought it again for another playthrough with the expansions, as my previously owned version was on a long lost GOG Galaxy account.

The atmosphere, the story, the music, the gameplay mechanics are all on point and have set the gold standard for any RPG I play.

Only minor bugs remain, which I don't find gamebreaking at all. Haven't tried the game with mods (yet).

One of the best games of all time
Witcher 3 is a very good action rpg 

+pros
+ good story 
+ a very beautiful and really active world
+ a lot of good and well written side quests
+ in depth crafting and alchemy system

-cons
- a bit repetitive combat (alt click and all over again)
- some signs are a bit unuseful in fights (i am only using quen igni and some times yrden)

Death march difficulty
In my opnion every one should play the second playthrough in this difficulty
The game becomes a lot of more demanding and you are forced to use all the tools that game gives you(oils , potions...)

In conclusion,
I believe that witcher 3 is one of the best game but it has some throwbacks like all games. At death march the game become a lot better and can give you more variety

The fact that it is an RPG and has no grind makes this incredibly refreshing. Every quest you set out on feels like a real mission with purpose , in a universe where currency actually feels like it has value and things in general are hard to come by. Every dialogue I have feels like it was well thought our by the devs and not something that was put in there as a filler which makes me feel even more immersed in the universe. The character design is beautiful, as well as the overall environment. As for the combat it may feel abit janky at first but once you get the hang of it it flows alright. It definitely deserves the praise it has revolving around it,and is for sure once of my top RPG games.It started off abit slow to begin with but after playing it for a few hours I was hooked.

I know I'm late but, The Witcher 3... Where do I even start?

This game is for sure one of the best pieces of entertainment ever made, everything about it is amazing. The story is extremely well written, the environment is immersive, all of the characters have unique personalities, choices make a difference, the graphics are stunning(even almost 6 years later, at the time I'm writing this review), the amount of content this game has is impressive(took me 111 hours to finish one playthrough with all the DLC'S, not going for 100%) the DLC's are basically entirely new games, etc. I could go on and on writing about every good aspect of this game, but it would take too long.
One of the things that amazes me the most is how deep the story and the world you play in are, and how much your choices impact on basically everything that happens later on in the game.
The Witcher's universe is interesting in every aspect of it and it's absolutely worth reading the books or watching the Netflix series for some context before playing the game(not required tough, you can enjoy the game anyways).
It may sound cliche but what saddens me the most about having just finished the game for the first time is the fact that I won't ever be able to play it for the first time again, but the game still has replay value, so I'm sure in one or two years I can come back to this game and have a different experience, and I'm certain it won't let me down.
I'm looking forward to a new game in this world, CDPROJEKT RED certainly will do a good job.
Concluding, if you are in doubt wether buying the game or not, do it, I know you won't regret it.

P.S. If you notice any mistakes in my writing please consider I'm not a native speaker. Anyways, thanks for reading this review, and I hope it helped you in some way.
A good game to kill some time and enjoy beautiful scenario, and the taste of adventure! I played on easy anyway!!

I'm by no means a hardcore gamer, and this is the first "Review" but it's really just my personal opinion. Game is a lot of fun to play, really addicting. 
The only thing I wish I had done different before spending nearly 60 hours on the game is pick a harder difficulty, picking easy might help at the beginning, but it sure made the game a little less fun down the line. 
So this post is for you "not so serious" gamer's looking for that game that you can just loose yourself in and have fun! Just be brave and play on a harder level then Easy!

[h1]Background:[/h1]

After 173.7 hours, I finished my first playthrough of the game. The one suggestion I read years ago was you didn't need to have played Witcher 1 or 2 to play Witcher 3. I'd played Witcher 1: Enhanced Edition years ago and loved it. I don't remember every detail given it was years ago since playing, but the majority of the things you find in Witcher 3, are based in Witcher 1: The characters: Yennifer, Triss, Zoltan, Thaler, etc. The scenery. The racism. The monsters (drowners, werewolves, etc.). The groups, Scoia'tael (which played more of a role in Witcher 1 than it did in Witcher 3). The fistfights. The names of cities. Etc. All of these were founded and established in Witcher 1. And the good news is Witcher 1 is both really inexpensive and because it was made in 2007, can work on a garbage computer. To my surprise, I also just discovered I also wrote a detailed review of Witcher 1 on April 1, 2017, highlighting many of the negatives in that game, with an update included in the review.

Onto Witcher 3:

[h1]Negative(s):[/h1]

-Convoluted leveling: Outleveled in Level Zones. One of the concepts that was difficult for me to grasp was the leveling in this game. Velen, which has a suggested minimum level of 5, has, for example, level 20 leshens that you're forced to avoid until you hit at least level 16 (the minimum suggested level of Skellige isles-which in the back of your mind, especially as you level up more and more are thinking, "I have to finish up with this area so I can move onto the next without being penalized"-and there were many lengthy quests that I did in Skellige especially where I received 1 xp because I'd leveled so much in Velen and Novigrad), or risk being mauled to death. More importantly, there is a sufficient amount of question marks throughout the map that consists of loot, potential quests, school gear diagrams, etc. that are out of your level's reach. This is true in Velen, Novigrad and the Skellige isles, etc., where you'll spend a lot of time. I was around level 20-22 when I ventured north-east of the map in the countryside outside of Novigrad. Nearly every-freaking-monster had red question marks indictaing that I was too underleveled to fight them. Annoyed, I stopped adventuring the area and went back to questing. The same was true in the south of Velen around the abandoned town of "Byways" where I encountered multiple overleveled ghouls that I later found out were safeguarding a meaningful storyline quest. A part of the problem with this is as you move on to new areas and keep questing to further the various main and secondary stories, you forget the monsters and areas you've neglected because you were outleveled.

-Locked out of Completing Quests. I'm kind of an anal completionist where I try to complete every quest given to me or that I accepted. There was one quest called, "The Things Men Do For Coin" where I was unable to complete it and transfer the quest from my "Treasure Hunts" to the "Completed" section of the menu because I'd looted the body prior when I was navigating the world and that area specifically. I'd tried multiple times looting it since to no positive conclusion. I then went online seeking a solution and found out people had issues not only with this quest, but with others as well that they weren't able to complete. It felt like I was being punished for navigating freely throughout the world and became more diligent not to loot or interact with anything that was covered in red given that it may be connected with a quest I don't know about. Another quest I was unable to complete was called, "Brothers in Arms: Skellige." In that quest, one of the benchmarks I needed to have met was to, "Help resolve the matter of the succession to the Skellige throne." The problem with this was that I was asked to help resolve this matter earlier and opted not to help, a decision that I had no understanding would penalize me later on concerning the main story. In this quest like the one mentioned earlier, I spent time attempting to understand how to further the main story on my own only to seek outside/online help where I found out this quest too could not be completed. Thankfully, I later learned this portion of the quest wasn't absolutely critical to the main story and I was still able to continue with the main story, though it would've helped somewhat.

-Confusion about Character Points Screen. I didn't learn this until after like 20-30 hours of playing, maybe even more, in the character points screen, when you level up, you have the option of selecting how you want to use your points and in which sections (combat, signs, alchemy or general). What I wasn't aware of was however I chose to distribute my points did not matter if I did not slot them in one of the 12 slots to the right (slots in which more become unlockable the more you level up). I noticed, for example, that one of the attributes I selected to spend a point was one called, "Sun and Stars" in the general section that allowed Geralt to regenerate health during the day. When I noticed I wasn't regenerating health, I suspected something was wrong. I went online and found other people too were confused as to why the attributes they chose weren't working, meaning other players were confused about this necessary slot mechanic as well.

[h1]Positive(s):[/h1]

+Amazing and engaging story with rich and capable lore with worthy subject matters including racism, persecutions of people based on race, religion, religious extremism, poverty (you'll encounter one type of NPC with many clones throughout the world who says, "help me, I'm dying of poverty" that is so true in our world today), classism, ideology, superstitions, traditions, violence, peace, heavy on politics, war, death, familial relations, justice/injustice, etc.

+Story provides brilliantly logical/sensible justifications and dialogue

+Your choices matter (One example was there were multiple ways to handle a dispute with a certain character, most of them were relatively peaceful. One of the few ways was to push the issue which surprisingly led to that character attacking me and ultimately to that character's death. Their death was then mentioned multiple times as you progress through the game and is intertwined with the main story. Another example was there was a closed-door meeting with a certain character who was close to Geralt. I was nudged to trust the character who was close to Geralt and would have had to wait outside of the door during the closed-door meeting, with no understanding of the details of what was being discussed in the meeting. I bucked that, chose to be over-bearing and cautious and instead was privy to what was being discussed in the meeting. It was really impressive to see the duality.). 

+Beautiful world and scenery that makes you pause your questing/adventuring

+Open-world is both massive and free (I spent the first 100 hours largely without a horse because I didn't want to overlook or pass anything. I wanted to discover and see everything the world presented) 

+Economical (So much content for the price tag. I finished my first playthrough after 173.6 hours).

+Diverse fighting builds

+Varied activities to do to keep you from feeling the game is monotonous (main-story questing, secondary-story questing, side-quests, fist-fighting, adventuring, nature-viewing, GWENT!, card-collecting, horse-racing, unlocking locations, unlocking question marks, etc).



I plan on providing an updated review as I did with Witcher 1 years ago, but this one will undoubtedly take me a lot more time to update given how massive the game and how extensive the content is. First, though, I'm planning on providing separate reviews for the two DLCs (Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine) that I have yet to play.

I'm all out of characters to continue writing so I'm forced to conclude this review.

Over 50 hours were invested in playing and completing the stories of the Witcher 1 and 2 before delving into CDPR's final game in the trilogy. Another 75 hours was spent on this game alone. Although 5 days worth of time was spent playing this trilogy, The Witcher 3 (With DLC) proved it to be time well-spent. Before entering my list of pros and cons that will inevitably piss someone off because of some omission, I must preface it by saying that The Witcher 3 is probably the best game I have played with all aspects considered. Some of this game's highest highs are as follows:

Pros:
-The main characters that occupy this world truly feel alive. Our protagonists act like people who have meaningful and realistic goals. I could write a review on this one point itself, but to paraphrase: Characters like Geralt, Ciri, Triss, and Yennefer interact in dynamic relationship webs that make the world feel so alive. In games gone by, characters that Geralt knew largely interacted with just him, and not among each other. Playing from Geralt's perspective in The Witcher 3, each of the character interactions he witnesses give the impression that these people have a long history with one another.
-The graphics still hold up to snuff even after five years. Rejoice in the fact that you do not NEED any graphics mods whatsoever.
-The Witcher 3 handles the themes of moral ambiguity responsibly. Choosing between factions isn't like choosing the crap you took last night or today. Each faction or decision in the game provides noteworthy pros and cons that can make you really consider your impact on the world.
-The music of the Witcher 3 is generally exceptional for an RPG that is as bold and expansive as this
-The community has continued to prove that you can play The Witcher 3 with a diversity of playstyles regarding combat, dialogue, or general quest choices.
-Unlike many video games, The DLC in the Witcher 3 reliably hold up to these aforementioned pros. Too many video games fall in the pit trap of awkward DLCs that don't meld well with the base game.
-Gaunter O' Dimm continues to be a disturbing, yet captivating villain. His theme only bolsters his excellence as a villain.
-I understand that there isn't a large quantity of pros, but that is simply because each pro is meant to quickly and concisely praise the fundamental aspects of RPGs that this game nails.

Cons (Oh no, what do you mean this game isn't perfect!):
-The facial expressions in characters is rather shallow, While the bottom half of their faces are quite expressive, there is little movement in the eyes and brows. The characters seem to play their best poker faces above the mouth.
-While there is a lot of combat styles to choose from initially, The Witcher 3 is quite punishing for playing as sort of jack of all trades among alchemy, signs, and swordplay (which is pretty counter-intuitive to who a great Witcher should be)
-This aforementioned con effectively renders The Witcher 3's combat as a spamfest of your choosing
-While there is much enjoyment out of replaying the story, the long stretches of exploration and combat makes replaying feel somewhat tedious
-Eredin looks edgy AF under the mask
-The modding community continues to be as anemic as the rest of the trilogy
-In what I can only call an attempt to distance itself from its previous installments, The Witcher 3 unnecessarily excludes characters like Iorveth, Saskia and Siegfried to its own detriment.

Despite some technical issues that hold this game back from genuine perfection, it is a damn near replication. I truly do insist that you at least play the first two games. Otherwise, you'll look at people like Radovid or Phillapa Eilhart and say "Who the fuck is that?" Even book characters like Fringilla Vigo and Dykstra will leave non book readers confused. Despite these intimidating facts, this game is still more than enjoyable without prior knowledge. If this game is on sale, I implore you to pick it up.

I tried refunding but because I sat on this game for months before trying it, they wouldn't let me refund it. One of the best games I have ever played. You will forever be comparing everything you play to the Witcher 3 and it will frustrate you, because most other games cannot compete with this beast. If you play games like Fallout, Skyrim, Red Dead, The Last of Us or Batman Arkham series - we probably have similar taste. So here are some of the reasons why the Witcher tops them all: 

1. Narrative: the main story is good, but the side quests and DLC's are fantastic. Quests require you to investigate, hunt, fight and make the right choices. Outcomes vary massively and can depend on the tiniest decision.
2. The characters and dialogue: there is a fair amount of talking in this game, but its interactive and written so well. If you like story-driven games, you won't be bored.
3. The amount of detail is staggering. The scenery, the cities, the people, the various landscapes, hidden locations - some crazy attention to detail went into this game and most people will never find it.
4. The gameplay is awesome and you can switch play-style deep into the game (i.e. move from magic to alchemy to combat at any point). Its satisfying, yet never overly easy. 
5. I can't leave a review and not mention the music. You might not notice it much at first, but the soundtrack to this game is phenomenal and it adds so much to the overall experience.

If you love fantasy, gritty fairy tales, romance, interesting stories and good humour, play it. 
If you're a gamer, play it.

I just finished the main quest at 80 hrs, and i could have taken more time with all the side quests and witcher contracts, but the writing was amazing, and the graphics were next level at parts... the customization is minimal from some other fantasy rpgs that ive played in the past, and the gameplay was easy to grow accustom to, while not super challenging on the normal difficulty, there were many moments where i was changing up my battle style. Most importantly, save often as the story lines have so many twists and turns that if you skip through a scene too quickly you might quickly regret it. Almost all 80 hours were enjoyable and very little grinding(mostly all by my own accord) 5/5 I have yet to play the dlcs but am looking forward to it, all i can say is take your time with the main quest and have fun the whole way.

This game is one of the best games of the previous decade. The graphics - even though the game is 5 years old by now are still beautiful, the voice acting well done, the gameplay mechanics are good, the story is amazing, and the music is epic. The game is really long, however you will never feel bored, because leveling up becomes a delight due to the fact that the side quests entail interesting stories. The game is totally worth it even at full price. If you have the time, buy it, and step into the beautiful world of Witcher 3
Very good, very long. I like it long.

it's basically how I remember Skyrim with rose-tinted glasses. Huge open world. things to see and do in every corner you find.
i.e. modern Skyrim, but all the quests are actually good.

the good:
* epic main story
* good/decent visuals
* a ton of fun side quests. some funny some genuinely good, none were actually bad

meh:
* limited carry weight, but easily "fixed" by buying a bag for the horse (base is 65, can add up to 100 with bags for a total of 165. most weapons are ~1 some chest pieces are ~12. most materials are 0)
* combat is pretty meh. can be fun, but it's pretty buggy in terms of lock on and when things do and do not hit.
* bugs (3 crashes for me in ~100 hours) some minor visual glitches. but nothing too bad. occasionally funny.

bad:
* nothing?
* The Gwent quests may require a bit of "save scumming" as there's no good mulligan system. with some bad hands you just can't win.

Immerse yourself in Gwent: the greatest collectible card game ever made, with a side of open-world exploration.  As you gain better cards to upgrade your deck, you will uncover an engaging story â€“ political intrigue, romance, and the fight to stop the Wild Hunt â€“ and visit new lands full of interesting and endearing characters.  Gwent will keep you hooked for hours!  And when you need a break from playing cards, the rich landscapes will bring much delight.

This is my favourite game ever so far. Looks great, interesting characters, lifely world and an awesome story. Since I just cared for the story and the world I played it on easy mode, so i cant say much about the fighting system lel, seems fine tho. The way i played it, it was a hack and slash with casting runes in between, pretty fun. But like mentioned before story, world and geralts character is what make this game a gem for me.

Depois desse jogo temo ter ultrapassado uma barreira indesejada: Nenhum jogo vai me surpreender, divertir e ter tanta imersividade quanto The Witcher 3. 
 Com 230 horas jogadas explorando tudo e concluindo histÃ³ria + DLCs, e jÃ¡ quero repetir imediatamente!! Vou me segurar e tentar me distrair com outros jogos pendentes, porÃ©m com certeza voltarei a esse jogo, ou melhor, a franquia, pois quero 'maratonar' os trÃªs jogos novamente, fazendo escolhas diferentes e explorando cada canto que nÃ£o fiz na primeira vez.
 DifÃ­cil analizar completamente essa obra de arte, mesmo sabendo que nÃ£o Ã© para todos. Um jogo extenso, completo, totalmente bem escrito e com detalhes incrÃ­veis na histÃ³ria, mesmo nas side quests. GrÃ¡ficos nÃ£o devem nada mesmo para os dessa geraÃ§Ã£o, ambientaÃ§Ã£o, musica, enredo, personagens, desenvolvimento, escolhas, habilidades, combate, liberdade, exploraÃ§Ã£o.  SÃ³ nÃ£o recomendo a aqueles que nÃ£o gostam de 'muitas side quests', apesar de nÃ£o serem obrigatÃ³rias; e aos que nÃ£o gostam (nÃ£o entendo como) de histÃ³ria longa. 
 
 Pontos negativos? Existem. Fazem diferenÃ§a? Pra mim nenhuma. Alguns bugs e leves 'inconsistÃªncias' que sÃ£o claramente devido a limitaÃ§Ãµes da engine e tecnologias de quando feitas, e nÃ£o por incapacidade, mal planejamento ou preguiÃ§a como na maioria dos jogos por aÃ­. 
 Finalizando, o maior problema desse jogo mesmo, Ã© que ele termina. E fica num pedestal completamente difÃ­cil de ser tirado.

Simplesmente a melhor porra da historia

I'm a die-hard fan of the Fallout series. I've never played anything w/ Swords and Sorcery since my D&D days back in the 1980s. I LOVE The  Witcher 3!
Thanks to a massively powerful PC, I'm able to play this at Ultra settings across the board. The visuals are stunning, both in gameplay and during cut-scenes. The combat is fun and fluid, the monsters are scary as heck the first time you run into one of their kind, and the mechanics are simple. It took me a few levels to get the hang of placing character points and properly dealing w/ traders, herbalists, etc., but now it's a piece of cake.
The writing - both in spoken dialogue and the books/pages you find - are first-rate. I judge these by a simple rule: does it seem natural - like if that's what that character would say/write - or does it come across as someone sitting at a keyboard and typing the first thing that comes to their head? In both cases in The Witcher 3 I can say, without hesitation, that it's the former by a country mile.
The conversation trees are incredibly fun. You can decide to play coy, mean, or just be direct. I can't wait to play several times through again in order to check out the avenues the speech choices I didn't make this time i order to see where they lead me.
I have the expansion packs but haven't tried them out yet. I'm definitely looking forward to them.
Get this game! You won't be sorry.

O universo te conquista desde o primeiro minuto de jogo. Eu to completamente apaixonado!

O jogo Ã© muito bom, histÃ³ria perfeita, envolvente, boa jogabilidade e grÃ¡ficos razoÃ¡veis.
A parte negativa Ã© que em algumas missÃµes vocÃª fica um pouco perdido pois o jogo nÃ£o fale onde vocÃª tem que ir e nem o que fazer quando chegar lÃ¡, no mapa nÃ£o aparece nada tambÃ©m como guia.

# Resumo

A great game to buy in 2020.

For the record this is the only review i have ever written on here. 

In summary it is very hard to pick fault with this game. Having completed it i feel genuine emotion, testament to the quality of the writing and depth of story. 

Not just the main story but the side quests. All of which make you feel like you are there with a purpose..........being a Witcher. 

Its not too open world, its not too linear, its not too ambitious, its pretty much perfect.

For my part asa 40 something year old who has been playing games since i was 10 it is the best piece of entertainment (including books, film....TV (Game of thrones is up there as well)) ive ever been part of.

If you've never played it i genuinely do envy you.

Another reviewer wrote something along the lines of the worst thing about this game is that they will never get to play it again for the first time. I entirely agree with that sentiment.
Best single player game I have ever played. (once you remove the nostalgia factor from games from early childhood)

The Best Game Open World I Play

[h1]Overview a.k.a. TL, DR:[/h1]

Played many medieval/fantasy-themed games in the past, whether it's RPG, strategy, or action-RPG, and I'm just 'dived' into The Witcher franchise recently because my PC finally good enough to play it properly. I have to say, this game in particular are one of the games that actually got me excited for its storyline alone. Never got this (wholeheartedly) hooked before. Great!

[h1]The Good[/h1]

[list]
[*] Beautiful visuals, still holds up even today
[*] Huge enough game world for an RPG
[*] Believable story, even for someone who doesn't indulge in medieval fantasy and preffered Sci-Fi for an RPG game
[*] The HUD are fairly crowded, but not intrusive enough for me
[*] Expansive crafting and character development system
[*] The music and sounds in general.
[*] Controls are fairly easy to comprehend 
[*] Supportive elements of the games like minigames or other activities in game doesn't really interfere with the story
[*] Expansive graphical settings and post-processing like AA actually not that taxing in this game, unlike others
[*] Actually made me save scumming to get an all good ending on my first playthrough, but the save file are fairly small unlike Fallout/Skyrim/Football Manager
[*] Could actually bully town guard without fear of getting hanged afterwards
[*] Racial prosecution simulatorâ„¢
[*] Gwent
[*] Geralt's drawing skills
[*] The fair maids of the northern realms ( Í¡Â° ÍœÊ– Í¡Â°)
[/list]

[h1]The Bad and the Ugly[/h1]

[list]
[*] I know it's Geralt's story, but If Geralt actually got an amnesia or something like in the first game (?) RPG perfectionists could have more freedom to develop the character and Geralt not knowing a lot of things already at the start could be more believeable[spoiler]like, a lot more creature should be listed in bestiary already, or a lot more crafting/alchemy diagrams should already exist at the start.[/spoiler]
[*] Many aspects should be in the vanilla game, like all quest pins should appear in world map (yes this have been mitigated with mods, but some people just wanna play and enjoy the game)
[*] NPC faces (at least that we can interact with like merchants) are really similiar and not enough variety 
[*] In a dream world, there shouldn't be any leveling system on this game, only progressed through the story and gain/earn abilities like Skyrim (do more to get better), can't stand Geralt got bullied by mere Drowners at early game. I don't know, I might be a dimwit at fighting Drowners.
[*] Dammit even 100 hours of gameplay not enough to find more dirt on this game lmao, yeah it's that good
[/list]

[h1]10/10 would save scum for this game[/h1]

Esperaba mucho mÃ¡s la verdad, y ahora me doy cuenta de que es un juego absurdamente sobrevalorado.

Para empezar no es una crÃ­tica con hate o con rabia, puesto que de cierto modo disfrute del juego, hay muchas cosas las cuales decepcionan cuando lo juegasâ€¦ porque claro, todas las reseÃ±as positivas que lees son del tipo [i]â€œUna obra maestraâ€¦â€[/i] o [i]â€œPosiblemente el mejor juego de la dÃ©cadaâ€[/i] y piensas â€œesto debe ser un puto juegazoâ€. Cuando no es tan asÃ­.

The Witcher 3 tiene una buena historia y una amplia cantidad de misiones, por lo cual en ese lado nunca te vas a cansar, porque de un modo u otro son entretenidas y realmente serÃ­a un juegazo de no ser por los problemas que tiene.

Su jugabilidad es demasiado tosca; cuando empiezas a pelear es cuando las cosas fallan un poco. Que si, que tienes combos mamalones donde puedes decapitar a las personas e incluso se pone brevemente en cÃ¡mara lenta para que veas ese espectÃ¡culo de rico â€œgoreâ€, pero esto solo pasa en momentos muy contados y la mayorÃ­a del tiempo es: â€œPegar, esquivar, pegar, esquivarâ€¦â€ deja bastante que desear la verdad, que un juego donde prÃ¡cticamente la jugabilidad principal es darse de putazos con otros sea algo tan vacÃ­o.

El paisaje es en verdad algo espectacular, quitando el hecho que los pequeÃ±os pueblos sean un copia y pega, el resto estÃ¡ bastante bien hecho estÃ©ticamente, pero la mayorÃ­a del terreno estÃ¡ muy vacÃ­o; es decir, no hay casi nada interesante que hacer mÃ¡s que madre con algunos Sumergidos, pero esto tampoco es nada espectacular por el punto anterior (jugabilidad). AdemÃ¡s de esto su poca variedad de npcâ€™s es algo completamente absurdo, da bastante risa y pena a la vez que el mismo sujeto sea un mercader, un bandido, embustero o incluso un guarda.

Hay muchas mÃ¡s cosas, como que las cinemÃ¡ticas sean tan aburridas y largas. Cosas como el crafting o las skills son tan innecesarias. El movimiento del personaje es horrible y lo es el triple cuando vas en caballo. Cuando caes de una escalera o algÃºn borde de mÃ¡s de 2 metros te mueres. 

No todo es malo, obvio, tiene un apartado visual increÃ­ble, su interfaz es demasiado limpia y muy personalizable, y la historia que es algo atrapante.

[h1]ConclusiÃ³n:[/h1]

Les armes toujours les memes, les sorts toujours les memes, 5 dont 3 qui ne servent que tres peu. 200 potions, 5 utiles.

Et encore au bout d'un moment avec 50 quetes differentes dans le journal on se perd et on sature, effet de bordel enorme. Faut aller le soir dans deux endroits, on choisi, mais pas grave l'autre quete attendra, et le perso va meme attendre 2 semaines devant le lieu ou on doit le rencontrer, logique. RÃ©alisme proche de 0.
Respect de l'oeuvre, 5/10 (bon aprÃ¨s l'auteur des romans Ã  une tendance pÃ©dophile perverse donc sur ce point c'est pas trop mal mais y a du cul sans raison, plus de putes ('catins') et de 'mecs louches' dans Novigrad que tous les autres mÃ©tiers ou descriptions rÃ©unis). Choisir Triss ou Yennefer, tu parles d'un choix, tu parles d'une modÃ©lisation de persos...., Yennefer est de plus superficielle et sans interet dans le jeu.
Les bugs, coincÃ© dans le dÃ©cor, le dÃ©cor rencontrant le dÃ©cor (les objets se croisent et se mÃ©langent), figÃ©, l'Ã©pÃ©e qui se range sans demander, sortir les poings et pas l'Ã©pÃ©e... HUD pas simple d'utilisation.
200 heures pour tout approfondir, vaut mieux etre chomeur. Et dur de se rappeler tous les dialogues parce que forcement on reprend apres avoir fait autre chose de sa vie et que l'on a oubliÃ© ce que l'on a fait il y a deux mois.
Et Mon Dieu les controles du perso dans les combats, c'est lent, ca rÃ©pond tardivement, trop de dÃ©calage, c'est pas nerveux. La moitie du temps il frappe a cotÃ© (je ne parle meme pas de Ciri qui est nulle et des bugs qui font que durant sa teleportation elle prend des degats) se retourner il n'y pense pas meme quand il n'y a personne devant lui. Les coups sur les boss passent au travers, plus de "bugs exploits" que de combat.
A cela quelques autres dÃ©fauts oubliÃ©s en cours.

Reste un bon jeu, mais y a mieux.
En rÃ©sumÃ© la moitiÃ© des quetes secondaires et les graphismes sont biens, le reste est entre pathÃ©tique et correct.


Note, Pour la tendance perverse de l'auteur je rappelle que dans les livres Ciri se fait violer mais que c'est prÃ©sentÃ© tout Ã  fait normalement. Un peu comme David Hamilton ou Roman Polanski voire la version Cohn-Bendit.

At the beginning you might feel like giving up playing it (at least I did) but I urge you to keep on going. You'll feel more and more immersed in the story, the new map regions will become even more eye catching and the side quests more fun.
All in all, an absolute must have in your library.

Le jeu nâ€™a pratiquement que des qualitÃ©s, on passe des heures dans cet univers sans voir le temps passer. Entre phases dâ€™explorations, quÃªtes principales et secondaires il y a une narration qui nous pousse toujours Ã  nous impliquer dans lâ€™aventure, sans parler des dÃ©cors et des musiques qui renforcent grandement cette immersion. Le seul dÃ©faut qui ressort selon moi pour lâ€™instant câ€™est la gestion de lâ€™inventaire qui est un peu longue Ã  maÃ®triser et nÃ©cessite un bon temps dâ€™adaptation.

So far even though i still have a lot to go in the story i can still tell you this game is 100% worth it. The combat is easy to learn but hard to master but if combat and swords are not your thing you can always use signs as a simple way to spice up gameplay. Exploring in this game is not like others as it is actually rewarding as you can find a lot of loot that can boost you very far in the early game, the only thing to watch out for is that level scaling is disabled by start so you'll run into a lot of overleveled monsters but in my opinion this is good as you can visually see your character getting stronger and more and more op. This game definitely has its rep for a good reason and i see no excuse for not picking this game up and giving it a try.

I don't find W3 to be the best game ever, as many seem to do. Yet, it is somewhat unique in that pretty much ANYTHING in the game (main quests, side quests, etc.) are, at the absolute worst, decent. It's simply a good time for a long time. 102 hours is a single playthrough of everything, doing almost all side quests.

Don't let my playtime fool you! I just bought the GOTY edition of this game on Steam (Highly recommended) after playing about 80 hours or so on Nintendo Switch. The game supports cross saves between platforms which I will be using going forward, and I hope my willingness to pay for the game twice is a testament to it's quality. On PC, this game is GORGEOUS, playing on maxed settings with an RTX 2070, but as my fellow Switch players will surely know, graphics aren't everything. The gameplay and story are equally compelling, and I consider this one of the greatest games I have ever played. I cannot recommend this game enough. The DLC is equally worthwhile, do yourself a favor and buy the GOTY edition. Buy it!!!

I got this game on sale quite a while ago, and played through it last year, I wasn't sure what I was getting into since I'm not big on Witcher lore and the first two games felt kinda alienating to play for me. To my surprise, I ended up really liking and enjoying this game. Now I'm not really into this D&D/Medieval themed games or media usually and I don't usually like how austere, confusing, or uninvolving most RPGs feel, but this feels very much so playable unlike those games, and even though there's stuff that I still don't fully understand, for the most part it's either simple enough that you don't have trouble grasping concept or you come to understand how they work over time, and you can easily finish the game even without really understanding everything about them. Regardless, the story is fairly simple, you look for Ciri, the protagonist Geralt's figurative daughter and protege, who is on the run from an entity known as the Wild Hunt, as you look for clues and traces through three vast regions of swamp-infested Velen, urban centers of Oxenfurt and Novigrad, and the Nordic-like Isle of Skellige. There's even more with the DLC but the base game is expansive enough on it's own that it's kinda hard to run out of things to do, whether it be side quests, contracts, or treasures of some sort. Even though as I said I'm not big on Witcher lore you do end up becoming interested in the socio-economic and political situation of this world and your actions do define the ending as well as ending for various characters, and I should mention, it is vital to have interesting and well-written characters in relatively simple stories like these and well they nail that here too. Although Geralt is pretty lacking in his ability to display emotions due to his mutations, you still get some emotional moments and since he is the player's mouth-piece you do feel some relation to him, and everyone else, fellow witchers, Triss, Yennefer, Ciri, and others, are great characters on their own and there is a joy to interact with people overall. There is not much else to say here, great game.

Breathtaking. I was enjoying the game since the very beginning until the last drop of the absolutely stunning story experience. Game mechanics are perfect, very nice crafting system, many side quest and little side stories (some of them also affects the main story line). Sometimes I found a few bugs but nothing what would annoy me. Anyway the game is perfect in many ways and there is not many negatives. When I think about it I could mentiont just useless witcher armor sets (could be more epic when they are so hard to craft - you can find much better armour easier) and few bugs which you sometimes encounter.

What can I say? I've really enjoyed playing this game. I've been searching for something to get lost into, the kind of game you loose track of time while you're playing it. For me....this is that game. You can focus on your main quest or do side quests or just plain explore. The detail in the world is fantastic. Interaction with characters and monsters....this game has it all. For just getting back into gaming, glad i found this title.
Lots of story, Lots of Monsters, Lots of killing

A mixed review really, this game has elements from other games that I enjoy and some I do not. The story is very anime in theme but done nicely. I just couldn't get into this one. I even modded it to make the grind less, which I have only done to one other game previously, still couldn't get into it. I am quite sure many players will enjoy this game but to me the play is hollow. The story is quite good, just mixed feelings about the play.

Definitivamente uno de los mejores juegos que he jugado en mi vida. Casi 100 horas de juego incluidos los DLC's y aun tengo cosas para hacer, misiones que terminar y sigue resultando tan atractivo y entretenido como el primer momento.
La historia es excelente y atrapante, la jugabilidad 10/10. La dificultad es intermedia lo que lo hace desafiante y entretenido sin llegar a ser frustrante.
Jugue las 3 entregas de la franquicia y realmente son excelentes, cada entrega mejora por sobre la anterior y se siente completamente refrescante al ser un juego completamente distinto en cuanto a jugabilidad y graficos pero sin perder la esencia de la saga.

Witcher 3 ist overall das beste Rollenspiel welches ich je gespielt habe (erstes RPG war Bards Tale 1 auf dem C64). Es ist absolut balanced und die Storyline ist vielschichtig und erwachsen erzÃ¤hlt. Technisch sieht es auf eine 1060 extrem gut aus. Ich mag zwar lieber SciFi RPG Settings doch das Spiel zieht einfach jeden in seinem Bann mit dem Storytelling und der wunderschÃ¶nen lebendigen Umgebung. Technisch ist die Charakterentwicklung nachvollziehbar und logisch. Einziger winzig kleiner Kritikpunkt ist die recht geringe Waffenauswahl fÃ¼r Geralt. Meiner Ansicht nach machen halt nur die beiden Schwerter Sinn. Hellebarden oder KnÃ¼ppel finde ich sinnlos. Wenn ich andere RPGs ansehe gibt es da mehr Futter. Aber das ist meckern auf dem hÃ¶chsten Niveau. Ein Muss fÃ¼r jeden Spieler und vielleicht fÃ¼r viele RPG Vermeider der Einstieg in ein tolles Genre. Leider gibt es viel zuwenig Spiele wie dieses. Vor allem in Richtung ScFi (eigentlich nur 3: Wasteland, Fallout, Outer Worlds).

Great stories, setting, monsters, and lore. Tons of mods that can improve the game.
But the combat is the weakest part of the game. It is a combination of choreography and hitbox system, which in this case resulted in an overall shallow system. Get it when you really want to play it in 2020. When you are not sure if you like it DONT BUY IT. When you like this type of Games go for it.

hayatÄ±nÄ±zda gÃ¶rebileceÄŸiniz en gÃ¼zel rpg oyunlarÄ±dan olan witcher 3 Ã¼eÄŸer bir rpg oyunu severseniz  oynamanÄ±zÄ± kesinlikle tavsiye ederim
possibly the best experience i have ever had with a game.

So i have previously play similar RPGs to the Witcher III (Two Worlds II, Gothics, Skyrim etc.), but none of them reachs such a qualitty and depth. I bought Witcher III with all DLCs and expansion packs for 15 â‚¬ and it was my best bargain on Steam yet. 

I would like to point out some things in which Witcher III excels. First one is the attractivness and uniqueness of main storyline and even of side quests, which really stands out among other titles. I guess main storyline is so good, because is based on the books, but in the end I have experinced games based on the books and non of them were so brilliantly well put together. In main storyline I felt like am in the movie never skipped a dialog. Everything was very dramatic and it really suprised my how the story evolved and ended and i have so much empathy for wide variety of all the characters i have met in the game. Even side quest are very sophisticated and very fun. I quarantee u will not experience boredom and stereotype like in some other titles.

The whole world is huge and enviroment is so gorgeous and it does not appear static, but rather very dynamic. The athmosphere is also very good, due to its cinematicness and beatuful soundtracks. I was also suprised how many unique armours, weapons and staff like that u can find or craft and how many secret places u will explore and also how many different monsters and opponents u will fight. 
The experinece is really thrilling. I spend 106 hours with main storyline and some sidequests, however I can still spend so much more time on sidequests, alchemy and crafting unique items and cool staff. Also as u level up u will modify ur Geralt by yourself, dont expect skilltree like in Path of Exile, but I end it up with lvl 52 and there was still many things to do with the character modification.

I simply love this game and in the end I highly recommend Witcher III, u will definitely not regret buing it.

Love this game -- one of the best, if not THE best, RPG ever made. Decisions made throughout the game genuinely impact the storylines and outcome. Suitably difficult boss fights, especially in the expansion packs (which I highly recommend -- they add many hours to gameplay). Wonderfully detailed world well worth exploring.

Great game with good graphics to follow up with the amazing story telling. This game has consequences to every decision you have made for each quest, which makes your choices all the more impactful as you craft your path as a witcher

Excellent role-playing game. Deeply rich story and setting, bordering the overwhelming. The world feels alive, and the arc of feeling overwhelmed by to opponents to hunting down every single monster is very satisfying. I felt like combat wasn't as varied as it was in other games, but it's not a cakewalk by any means, and tackling challenges well above your level by proper preparation with oils and potions feels very thematic. Hunting down recipes for crafting these upgrades is then likewise a very rewarding thing, and gives you real incentive to explore this beautifully crafted world.

There's a reason CD Project Red acquired such high status, and this illustrates that reason perfectly. There's no need to have played the prior two witcher games (they're nowhere near as good), but if you haven't, you're going to want to pay attention to the exposition.

this game is objectively very good

I have a love-hate relationship with this game. The storyline is great. The graphics and cut scenes are well polished. The voice acting is superb. I really can't say enough good stuff about it. 

However, I don't like the grim-dark nature of the game. I don't like that the main character is a mercenary rather than a hero. I don't like that the people in it with only a few rare exceptions are so utterly wretched that you frequently get backstabbed by those that hire you or that you end up killing them because they are such horrible monsters. 

Despite all the exceptional work that went into this game, the jaded world made me go back to playing Skyrim. 

Do I recommend it for all the exceptional quality of the game, absolutely. This game isn't a product. It is art. However, it is jaded art, so I can only look at it for so long before I have to go to something else that makes me happy.
What else can I say other than this is a freaking masterpiece. Beautiful world, characters, music, a truly immersive experience that all RPG fans must try

Would have never bought this game if I wasn't gifted it because I played WItcher 1 and 2 and had a terrible time both of the times, but a good friend gave it to me and I think it's one of the best action adventures with RPG elements out there now.

The story has some points that upset me, the world is kind of simplistic, pessimistic and... boring in its presentation of a kinda low fantasy medieval place, and sometimes when you're made to make a choice, the consequences make absolutely no sense. A lot of the characters behave irrationally mostly to enforce gritty dark fantasy, and these things all bothered me.

But the atmosphere is great, Geralt is cool, the combat is fun, the whole Witcher lifestyle is presented very well. The landscape is beautiful, the areas are well-designed, and the different RPG elements are also kind of nice. I did spoiler myself on how to get the best ending because of course the way to get it is equally nonsensical, but I'm glad I did it, because I walked away with a positive impression of Witcher 3 for it.
This game is too good. Well played story line.. realistic ..  ++

This was GOTY for a reason. Combat is nothing truly special, but it's still fun. Unless playing on Death March you can more-or-less ignore potions. The story is where this game shines though; it's honestly the best story in a game that I've ever played.

This game is so long, but such a great story experience even if the combat is a little lacking.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is one of my favorite games from the 2010s. The story is interesting and the characters are multi-faceted and have their own morals, values, and ambitions. Your choices throughout the game can affect the characters, your relationship to them, and story around you positively and negatively. The combat is simple yet fun, and the open world is diverse and filled to the brim with side content to complete. Alongside the incredible main story, the game has two of the best DLCs I've ever played, namely Blood and Wine. I've only played through the game once, and haven't come close to completing everything there is, but nonetheless I think this game is a must play.

One of, if not the best game I've played. I got immersed, i cried, i got mad, i laughed, and i enjoyed almost every moment of this game. It may be a long game, but its worth it. The side quests can be fun, annoying and tedius, but often give more to the world, story, or arsenal. Speaking of Arsenals, the amount of weapons, items, potions and bombs make combat never the same. Sure you have a silver sword for monsters, but what if you cast a spell then threw some bombs at that monster, or what about shooting it from atop your horse with a crossbow while avoiding its deadly strikes. You can prepare for every monster and situation, from monsters to humans, you wont lack in tools to kill.

While cdpr's latest game may be shit, this one is gold. Well worth the money spent, and time spent.

Undecided for two years; whether to try the game or not. I ended up buying it on the last sale for 20â‚¬, the GOTY edition, and I fired it up a few weeks ago after finding myself bored one night.

This game is probably the best game I've ever played. Everything, from the soundtrack to the story line, is spectacular.The characters in this game,the enviroment,the mobs...I cant't even find the proper words for these.
Sincerely, after playing this game, I don't really like the other games anymore.I can't find a story that keeps me interested like in this game.Even the main Villain in this game is so awesome, i mean it.

One of the best RPGs I've played. World is vast, interesting and dangerous. Characters have depth and variety. Every piece of content seems worthy of my time.

I have played this game time and time again, played the same content over and over again and still i like to play it from time to time and waste my life in this game. The leap from the first and second game is uncanny and the gameplay and story reached new heights even comparing to the best of the genre. The world is free roam with maps so rich in content that you will waste weeks just exploring it. The dlc for this game could have been their own games with how much content and great the narrative is. IF there is a game that could be called game of the decade for me is this, and Will allways try to return to with when i feel like it. 10/10

Easily one of the most well refined and crafted RPGs of all time. The story is engaging, the writing is fantastic, characters are memorable and the combat is good, (though not as good as a game like Dark Souls or Bloodborne, seeing how this game is more about story). The Witcher is a phenomenal RPG franchise. My money was well spent. Geralt is a great protagonist and his relationships with other characters is amazing.

Puan 8.5/10
When CD Project was a great gaming company.

After playing the game but never finishing it when it was released on PS4, I came back to playing this in 2020 on PC. Don't know how my playstyle changed, but this time I have a much better time with the combat system and the overall difficulty of the game. This way the really awesome story can be enjoyed and the game just feels way more immersive.

If you liked the idea of the game but didn't have a great time playing it, maybe it's worth revisiting.

Exceptional game, but we all know that. It's the Witcher. You know why it's good

Yes gameplay is mostly braindead. Yes the random events expect you to act without information you should easily be able to get to get "muh morally grey" point across and yes, difficulties mean nothing since higher difficulties just add more health to the borderline mentally challenged AI.
But behind that is still a game that is just comfy to be in. Riding around to a fantastic soundtrack finding things in the massive world and doing contracts for villagers who are probably the product of generations of inbreeding is just peak comfy.

PS. Don't do the question marks in the water in Skellige. It's not worth it.

For sure one of the best games ever made. It's one of those games that gets you so attached to literally every main character so that when you know the end is near you try to purposely drag it out by doing every side quest (the side quests in this game are phenomenal and have rich stories of their own, they are never just fetch quests, and if they are fetch quests there will always be an unexpected twist or a secret ending that you can easily miss), getting the best gear, talking to every main character, etc. The only bad thing about the game is that when you finally finish it you will get depressed for a whole week.

Now that I passed the 200 hours mark, I feel like I could give a proper review.
+ The environment is astounding
+ The story is richer than Jeff Bezos
+ The butterfly effect is actually a thing
+ The amount of abilities and enhancements is just insane
+ The music is almost always on point
+ The graphics, on a 144hz monitor are just gorgeous, despite being a 2015 release
+ Insane amount of side quests and possibilities to just "run around and kill stuff"
+ Option to save your progress at almost any given time, even in the middle of a mission
+ GWENT

- The quest rewards are relatively small (coin-wise)
- The items are very level-dependent, so even if you finish a quest with recommended character level of 20, whilest being level 13, you won't get a level 19/20/21 item, but a level 12/13/14/15 items
- The Wraiths
- Some glitches are still present (like ... you could literally get stuck somewhere), but on the bright side - those places are narrowed (at least based on my experience) to some places where you shan't be actually going. For the most part, no glitches are present

Overall, if you are into that genre and you are wondering whether the game is worth the money or not - it is. It absolutely is. The first day when I played it, I was playing for 16 hours straight ... my whole day off got sucked into Geralt's adventures.

Had to say the initial learning curve was a bit steep for me, but after 20+ hours I got familiar with the system and truly started to enjoy the story and the RPG side of the game. Highly recommend for RPG lovers, I didn't go for hard settings, only normal adventure level, I can see if people are seeking more challenges can be satisfied with the death march mode, overall a great game! Definitely much longer than the RPGs I am used to thou.
