Lo ammetto, un po' partivo prevenuto.. ma dico che merita giocarselo. Se scontato, poi, soprattutto avendo praticato gli altri due.. non si puÃ² evitare di metterlo in libreria!

In generale, senza dilungarmi. Bella la grafica, l'interfaccia pulita, paesaggi mozzafiato, sfide interessanti. Un buon erede del capitolo precedente, anche se mooolto piÃ¹ vasto. Equipaggiamento gestito bene, viene pure voglia di andarsene in cerca dei pezzi (per fortuna ci sono gli indicatori in mappa).

Wild Hunt. Personaggi in linea con il passato, con molteplici riferimenti ai capitoli pregressi. Storia molto clichÃ© ma lo stesso avvincente, l'epilogo non me l'aspettavo e mi Ã¨ piaciuto. Il mondo e le questline (anche le secondarie) sono resi bene, c'Ã¨ sempre quel sapore da fiaba che non svanisce mai; alcuni veri e propri piccoli gioielli di scrittura sparsi qua e lÃ  che valgono l'acquisto anche da soli (spesso nelle secondarie). Giocato a livello normale, non ho avuto grosse rogne negli scontri, ottimo! Unica pecca? Tre zone immense con troppi "punti di domanda sulla mappa": non li ho fatti tutti, a un certo punto stroppiano. Impressioni: buone

HoS. Il clichÃ© dei clichÃ©. Nonostante ciÃ², molto ben scritta dal sapore agrodolce con un retrogusto amaro che arriva dopo. Personaggi ultracaratterizzati, o li ami o li odi. Ho forse troncato un pezzo dell'avventura, ma ci stava e quindi va benissimo cosÃ¬. Finale cercato e ben scritto. Apprezzata l'idea di ampliare i set di equipaggiamento, fanno la differenza, bravi! Anche qui, fin troppi punti di domanda sulla mappa. Impressioni: discrete.

Blood & Wine. Ah, il mondo delle favole col sottofondo del ciclo arturiano, che volere di piÃ¹? Questline principale che all'inizio contrappone Luce e Tenebre con personaggi maggiori molto ben centrati. Le quest secondarie sono un tocco di classe, dove ancora una volta salta fuori l'anima dark dell'ambientazione. Le Mutazioni sono un'aggiunta interessante, ma non mi sono accorto di una loro estrema utilitÃ  a parte sbloccare slot per le abilitÃ . Unico punto assurdamente fastidioso per me, un particolare scontro in fasi in cui se muori devi ripartire dall'inizio (ho dovuto abbassare la difficoltÃ  per farcela).. capisco cosa dovesse rappresentare e magari ci sta ma.. se diventa frustrante ci perde il pathos. Anche qui, almeno 1/3 di punti di domanda inesplorati. Impressioni: ottime

Released in a time when companies were dead set on carbon copied quest fillers, the most enjoyable part of the Witcher for me is the refreshing fact that every quest, small or big, is hand crafted and unique. They even model out totally unique races and monsters for single side quests (such as the Sylvan or Godling). The attention and care given in this regard amplifies all of the other incredible qualities this game has.

Story and plot are exciting, relationships are unique, branching decisions have significant impact on outcomes, and combat has diverse mechanics for sword fighting, alchemy and magic that are best when combined. Some examples are:

You can pursue a romantic relationship with a character, realize they have used you for alternate motives and as a player decide to interpret this as benign politics or personal betrayal. Then the consequences of your words could restore that person to your side or end with a fight to the death. Either may be justifiable to your viewpoint and will affect long term game play.

Additionally when you approach combat you could go in blindly swinging your sword and likely deal with a difficult encounter, or you can read your bestiary around the monster (discovered in perhaps a lost tome) and apply proper oil to your blade, use appropriate defensive magics and decoctions to make the fight fair. When you realize this is the way of the Witcher, study and pre-fight tactics, you begin to grow more powerful than simply dumping points into attack power.

Some areas of the game that are a bit weaker are perhaps the loot and crafting aspects. There is generally not enough income in the game to craft or brew everything. Witcher contracts generally provide lower pay than you can really use to upgrade long term and will fall back to the age-old RPG tradition of hoarding loot up to your inventory limit and selling at various traders (which also just don't have that much currency). It was in this area I recommend getting the MOD: Double Quest Rewards which I feel is more balanced. Additionally it may seem counter intuitive, but paying blacksmiths to break down looted equipment will save you money in crafting more powerful items in the long term. Combine this with foot travel to collect the various herbs in the world to save a lot on Alchemy costs. Some of this balancing is not really learned until your second playthrough.

I have played all three Witcher series games, each nothing less than excellent. Witcher 1 was more linear and really shined through its story and dark world. Witcher 2 best compared to Dragon Age, somewhat "open world" areas with side missions but of course that powerful storyline. Witcher 3 however has re-scoped the expectations of the genre that I can safely say has not been outdone to this day (2021). Even CD Project Red's latest Cyberpunk game (when focusing on story, world building, hand-crafted quests and not on the launch issues) does not reach the levels achieved by Witcher 3 the Wild Hunt.

Luego de mÃ¡s de 100hs dentro de esta historia, considero que es un excelente juego, totalmente recomendado. 
La jugabilidad es muy buena y prÃ¡ctica, es posible acostumbrarse con facilidad.
Los mapas son extensos y muy detallados, con gran variedad de bestias, espectros, etc. 
Las ciudades tienen sus propios estilos y diseÃ±os, al igual que la poblaciÃ³n.
A pesar de su antigÃ¼edad, hoy en dÃ­a sigue siendo una excelente opciÃ³n, muy entretenido y casi nada que envidiarle a la nueva generaciÃ³n grÃ¡fica.
Al principio es algo complicado ir avanzando en la historia principal si no se realizan las misiones secundarias ya que no es sencillo subir de nivel. AdemÃ¡s de que las mismas, muchas veces refuerzan la historia principal brindando mÃ¡s informaciÃ³n sobre esta.
A partir del nivel 10, si se mantiene un buen nivel de misiones secundarias, se torna mÃ¡s sencillo avanzar.
Como consejo, recomiendo coleccionar todo lo que encuentran y a fin de evitar estar sobrecargado, guardarlo en un Alijo para luego venderlo en caso de ser necesario.
Por otro lado, tambiÃ©n es bueno recorrer todo el mapa a pesar de que muchas veces, es difÃ­cil eliminar a los enemigos que se encuentran en las diferentes locaciones, es por esto, que serÃ­a bueno hacer un paseo rÃ¡pido por todo el mapa y luego ir realizando las misiones.

Don't be put off by how old The Witcher 3 is - It's still a great game that is just so much fun all of the time, and the graphics hold up really well and are amazing. The main storyline is thorough and enjoyable and there are loads of side quests to enjoy. The map is also huge, but not so big that I wouldn't recognise where I was. I found myself completing almost all the side quests not to level up, but just because they're all a lot of fun. The only criticism would be how the side quests mostly serve as a distraction from the main story rather than complementing it. There's no need to rush though - take your time and enjoy all of the side quests! The combat is also simplistic but surprisingly good.

Overall, The Witcher 3 is still an amazing game today, and is absolutely worth the price. If it's also on sale, then go for it - you won't be disappointed

Just finished Cyberpunk 2077...This prompted me to finally review W3 WH.  It's rather difficult to believe the same studio made both.  This game represents the high water mark of game, dialogue and quest writing,  It also does an excelent job with the OW map.  Most OW map type RPGs devolve into a chase the map icon to do list which becomes grindy and tedious instead of engaging and immersive.

A good RPG side tracks you. It draws you in painlessly. It does not waste your time with filler just to clear an  icon.  You fire up the game entirely focused on a specific set of goals; then get sidetracked by a facinating story arc, quest, or activity having nothing to do with what you were aiming for.  Then your wife( or insert SO here) hands you a pillow and a small throw blanket after turning the heat down.  And you have no regrets...well you didn't need all your toes anyway.....


I didn't have this problem with Cyberpunk...The only times I failed to reach my goals for the play session was after my eyes started bleeding on yet another chase the stupid map icon that you otherwise don't give a damn about.  I can't even remember any characters names except mine which is a single letter...sigh  
I haven't played W3 in over a year and I still remember quite a number of quests and side arcs.  I shut off Cyberpunk (for the last time most likely) less than 2 days ago and I can barely remember the high points of the main plot.
Ill keep this short. The Witcher 3 is one of the best games i played. Great story and combat huge world its alot so be ready to get lost in the game.

I find The Witcher 3 to be a difficult game to judge.

On one hand it's an incredibly overrated game. The world of The Witcher 3 is shallow, it's all appearances which makes it end up feeling hollow with nothing really dynamic going on at all. The combat system feels floaty and janky. The RPG mechanics are shallow and the way the game handles equipment is horrendous. The game is also abandoned by the developers despite there being game breaking bugs left unfixed years later, so beware!

On the other hand the game does have excellent writing and acting with engaging side content. Despite the game marketing itself as an Action RPG I would recommend engaging the game as a visual novel instead. Put the game at whatever difficulty suits you best and immerse yourself in the story since it's the only thing this game does excellently. But since the game fails in many areas that I personally find crucial for an Action RPG I can not recommend this game.

Oh yeah, I also don't get why this was nominated as a Labour of Love. It's been years since the last DLC and they haven't released an official patch in a long time despite there still existing gamebreaking bugs years after release. I get that they're working on a next-gen remaster but god knows when it's going to be released or what state it will be released in.

Arguably the best entry in the Witcher series and one of the most dense open world games ever made, the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt and its expansions offers a riveting odyssey through an vast, bleak and beautiful continent for players to get lost in. While the RPG mechanics lack the open systems of the elder scrolls games, the compelling writing is enough of an incentive to keep players coming back to play for hours at a time. Player choice shapes the outcome of the narrative and it is riveting!

[u]Dislikes[/u]
-Aiming mechanics are okay (Again it's controller)
-Some missions you can get lost
